events: Christopher Columbus makes his first voyage to the New World opening a vast new empire for plantation slavery.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The first Africans arrive in Hispaniola with Christopher Columbus. They are free persons.
subject: Africans in the New World

events: The Spanish king allows the introduction of enslaved Africans into Spain's American colonies.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: The first enslaved Africans arrive in Hispaniola.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: Thirty Africans accompany Vasco Nunez de Balboa on his trip to the Pacific Ocean.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: Bishop Bartolome de Las Casas petitions Spain to allow the importation of twelve enslaved Africans for each household immigrating to America's Spanish colonies. De Las Casas later regrets his actions and becomes an opponent of slavery.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: King Charles I of Spain grants the first licenses to import enslaved Africans to the Americas.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: The first shipload of enslaved Africans directly from Africa arrives in the West Indies. Prior to this time, Africans were brought first to Europe.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: Hernan Cortez begins conquest of the Aztec Empire.
subject: Colonial Conquest

events: Enslaved Africans are used as laborers in Puerto Rico, Cuba and Mexico.
subject: Spanish Slavery

events: African slaves stage a rebellion in Hispaniola. This is the first slave uprising in the New World.
subject: Anti-Slavery Resistance

events: Spanish colonists led by Lucas Vasquez de Ayllon build the community of San Miguel de Guadape in what is now Georgia. They bring along enslaved Africans, considered to be the first in the present-day United States. These Africans flee the colony, however, and make their homes with local Indians. After Ayllon's death, the remaining Spaniards relocate to Hispaniola.
subject: Africans in the New World

events: Esteban, a Moroccan-born Muslim slave, explores what is now the Southwestern United States.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: An African from Hernando de Soto's Expedition into the Lower Mississippi River valley decides to remain behind to make his home among the Native Americans there.
subject: Africans in the New World

events: Africans serve in the New Mexico Expeditions of Francisco Vasquez de Coronado and Hernando de Alarcon.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The Spanish Crown abolishes Indian slavery.
subject: Emancipation

events: The first slaves directly from Africa arrive in the Brazilian city of Salvador.
subject: Portuguese Slavery

events: An expedition to Hispaniola led by John Hawkins, the first English slave trader, sparks English interest in that activity. Hawkins' travels also call attention to Sierra Leone. Hawkins is knighted in 1588 for his service in England's victory over the Spanish Armada.
subject: English Slavery

events: African farmers and artisans accompany Pedro Menendez de Aviles on the expedition that establishes the community of San Agustin (St. Augustine, Florida).
subject: Africans in the New World

events: Professor Bartolome de Albornoz of the University of Mexico writes against the enslavement and sale of Africans.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: Isabel de Olvera, a free mulatto, accompanies the Juan Guerra de Resa Expedition which colonizes what is now New Mexico.
subject: Africans in the New World

events: Mathieu Da Costa, a free black explorer, guides the French through parts of Canada and the Lake Champlain region of what is now New York state.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: Jamestown is founded in Virginia.
subject: Colonial America

events: Jan Rodriquez, a free sailor working for a Dutch fur trading company is assigned to live with and trade among the Native Americans on the island of Manhattan.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: Approximately 20 blacks from a Dutch slaver are purchased as indentured workers for the English settlement of Jamestown. These are the first Africans in the English North American colonies.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: The Pilgrims reach New England.
subject: Colonial America

events: The first African American child born free in the English colonies, William Tucker, is baptized in Virginia.
subject: 17th Century Black Religion

events: The first enslaved Africans arrive in the Dutch Colony of New Amsterdam (now New York City) with the Dutch West India Company. They quickly become the city's first municipal labor force, clearing land of timber, cutting lumber, cultivating crops, and constructing roads and fortifications.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: The first enslaved Africans arrive in what is now Connecticut.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: Slavery is introduced in Maryland.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: Dutch minister Everadus Bogardus summons a teacher from Holland to Manhattan Island to provide religious training to Dutch and African children. This is the first example of educational efforts in Colonial North America which are directed toward persons of African descent.
subject: Black Education

events: Massachusetts explicitly permits slavery of Indians, whites, and Negroes in its Body of Liberties. It is the first mainland British colony to legalize slavery.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Mathias De Sousa, an African indentured servant who came from England with Lord Baltimore, is elected to Maryland's General Assembly.
subject: Black Politics

events: Virginia passes a fugitive slave law. Offenders helping runaway slaves are fined in pounds of tobacco. An enslaved person is to be branded with a large R after a second escape attempt.
subject: Slave Laws

events: The New England Confederation reaches an agreement that makes the signature of a magistrate sufficient evidence to reenslave a suspected fugitive slave.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Merchant ships from Barbados arrive in Boston where they trade their cargoes of enslaved Africans for sugar and tobacco. The profitability of this exchange encourages the slave trade in New England.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: Dutch colonists transfer some of their landholdings in New Amsterdam to their former enslaved Africans as compensation for their support in battles with Native Americans. A condition of the land transfer, however, is the guarantee of a specified amount of food from those lands to their former owners.
subject: Emancipation

events: Connecticut legalizes slavery. Rhode Island by this date has large plantations worked by enslaved Africans.
subject: Slave Laws

events: The Dutch West India Company introduces new rules concerning slavery in New Netherlands. After gaining freedom, former slaves, for example, are required to give fixed amounts of their crops to the company. After the English capture of the colony, greater restrictions are imposed on free blacks and enslaved people.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Anthony Johnson, a free African American, imports several enslaved Africans and is given a grant of land on Virginia's Puwgoteague River Other free African Americans follow this pattern.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: Massachusetts enacts a law requiring all African American and Native American servants to undergo military training so as to be able to help defend the colony.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Rhode Island enacts first anti-slavery law in the British colonies. The law limits slavery to ten years.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Enslaved African and Indian workers bulid wall across Manhattan Island to protect the Dutch colony from British invasion. The site of the wall is now Wall Street.
subject: Slave Labor

events: Anthony Johnson successfully sues for the return of his slave John Casor, whom the court had earlier treated as an indentured servant.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: Fearing the potential for slave uprisings, Massachusetts reverses its 1652 statute and prohibits blacks from arming or training as militia. New Hampshire, and New York soon follow.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Virginia amends its fugitive slave law to include the fining of people who harbor runaway slaves. They are fined 30 pounds of tobacco for every night they provide shelter to a runaway slave.
subject: Slave Laws

events: A Connecticut law prohibits African Americans from serving in the militia.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Virginia reverses the presumption of English law that the child follows the status of his father, and enacts a law that makes the free or enslaved status of children dependent on the status of the mother.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Black and white indentured servants plan a rebellion in Gloucester County, Virginia. Their plans are discovered and the leaders are executed.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Maryland slave laws rules that all Africans arriving in the colony are presumed to be slaves. Free European American women who marry enslaved men lose their freedom. Children of European American women and enslaved men are enslaved. Other North American colonies develop similar laws.
subject: Slave Laws

events: In South Carolina every new white settler is granted twenty acres for each black male slave and ten acres for each black female slave he or she brings into the colony.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: A planned revolt of enslaved Africans and indentured servants is uncovered in Gloucester County, Virginia.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: In Virginia, the enslaved African's status is clearly differentiated from the indentured servant's when colonial laws decree that enslavement is for life and is transferred to the children through the mother. Black and slave become synonymous, and enslaved Africans are subject to harsher and more brutal control than other laborers.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Maryland establishes slavery for life for persons of African ancestry.
subject: Slave Laws

events: New Jersey and New York also recognize the legality of slavery.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Maryland enacts the first law in Colonial America banning marriage between white women and black men.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: England enacts strict laws regarding enslaved Africans in its colonies. An enslaved African is forbidden to leave the plantation without a pass, and never on Sunday. An enslaved African may not possess weapons or signaling mechanisms such as horns or whistles. Punishment for an owner who kills an enslaved African is a 15-pound fine.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Virginia declares that baptism does not free a slave from bondage, thereby abandoning the Christian tradition of not enslaving other Christians.
subject: Slave Laws

events: The Massachusetts legislature passes a law that enables its citizens to sell the children of enslaved Africans into bondage, thus separating them from their parents.
subject: Slave Laws

events: The Virginia Assembly enact law that allows all non-Christians who arrive by ship to be enslaved.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Massachusetts permits the separate sale of children of enslaved parents.
subject: Slave Laws

events: A Maryland law states that the conversion of enslaved African Americans to Christianity does not affect their status as enslaved people.
subject: Slave Laws

events: King Charles II of England charters the Royal African Company, which dominates the slave trade to North America for the next half century.
subject: The Slave Trade

events: Virginia law now bans prosecution for the killing of a slave if the death comes during the course of his his or her apprehension.
subject: Slave Laws

events: The Massachusetts legislature passes a law that forbids European Americans from engaging in any trade or commerce with an African American.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: An estimated 100,000 Africans are enslaved in the West Indies and another 5,000 are in British North America.
subject: Black Population

events: Nathaniel Bacon leads an unsuccessful rebellion of whites and blacks against the English colonial government in Virginia.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: Virginia enacts a law that forbids all blacks from carrying arms and requires enslaved blacks to carry certificates at all times when leaving the slaveowner's plantation.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Maryland laws mandate that children of European servant women and African men are free.
subject: Emancipation

events: A new slave code in Virginia prohibits weapons for slaves, requires passes beyond the limits of the plantation and forbids self-defense by any African Americans against any European American.
subject: Slave Laws

events: New York enacts its first slave codes. They restrict the freedom of movement and the ability to trade of all enslaved people in the colony.
subject: Slave Laws

events: New York law forbids enslaved Africans and Native Americans from having meetings or carrying firearms.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Quakers in Germantown, Pennsylvania denounce slavery in the first recorded formal protest in North America against the enslavement of Africans.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: By this year, all English colonies in America have enslaved Africans.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: Enslaved Africans and Native Americans in Massachusetts plan a rebellion.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: South Carolina enacts its first laws regulating slave movement and behavior.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Virginia enacts a new law which punishes white men and women for marrying black or Indians. Children of such interracial liaisons become the property of the church for 30 years.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: The success of rice cultivation in South Carolina encourages the importation of larger numbers of enslaved laborers especially from Senegal and other rice producing regions of West Africa.
subject: Agricultural Development

events: Rev. Samuel Thomas, a white cleric in Charleston, South Carolina, establishes the first school for African Americans in the British North American colonies.
subject: Black Education

events: Quaker religious leaders warn that members who own slaves may be expelled from the demonination.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: The publication of Samuel Sewall's The Selling of Joseph, is considered the first major condemnation of slavery in print in British North America.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: The New York Assembly enacts a law which prohibits enslaved Africans from testifying against whites or gathering in groups larger than three on public streets.
subject: Slave Laws

events: French colonist Elias Neau opens a school for enslaved African Americans in New York City.
subject: Black Education

events: The Colonial Virginia Assembly defined as slaves all servants brought into the colony who were not Christians in their original countries as well as Indians sold to the colonists by other Native Americans.
subject: Slave Laws

events: Africans in South Carolina outnumber Europeans, making it the first English colony with a black majority.
subject: Black Population

events: Great Britain's Queen Anne overrules a Pennsylvania colonial law prohibiting slavery.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: A public slave market opens in New York City at the east end of Wall Street.
subject: The Slave Trade

events: The New York City slave revolt begins on April 6. Nine whites are killed and an unknown number of blacks die in the uprising. Colonial authorities execute 21 slaves and six commit suicide.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: New York City enacts an ordinance that prevents free blacks from inheriting land.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: England secures the exclusive right to transport slaves to the Spanish colonies in America.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: The first enslaved Africans arrive in Louisiana.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: New Orleans is founded by the French. By 1721 the city has more enslaved black men than free white men.
subject: Colonial Slavery

events: South Carolina limits the vote to free white Christian men.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Boston imposes a curfew on non-whites.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: The French colonial government in Louisiana enacts the Code Noir, the first body of laws that govern both slaves and free blacks in North America.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Enslaved Africans and Native Americans revolt in Middlesex and Gloucester Counties in Virginia.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: South Carolina passes laws requiring enslaved people to wear clothing identifying them as slaves. Freed slaves are required to leave the colony within six months or risk reenslavement.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: An indentured black servant petitions a Massachusetts Court and wins his freedom after the death of his master.
subject: Emancipation

events: The first permanent black settlement in what will become the United States is established by fugitive slaves at Gracia Real de Santa Teresa de Mose (Fort Mose), Florida.
subject: Free Blacks in Colonial America

events: The first major South Carolina slave revolt takes place in Stono on September 9. A score of whites and more than twice as many black slaves are killed as the armed slaves try to flee to Florida.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Nineteen white citizens of Darien, Georgia petition the colonial governor to continue the ban on the importation of Africans into the colony, calling African enslavement morally wrong.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: During the New York Slave Conspiracy Trials, New York City officials execute 34 people for planning to burn down the town. Thirteen African American men are burned at the stake and another 17 black men, two white men and two white women are hanged. Seventy blacks and seven whites are permanently expelled from the city.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: South Carolina's colonial legislature enacts the most extensive slave restrictions in British North America. The laws ban the teaching of enslaved people to read and write, prohibits their assembling in groups or earning money for their activities. The law also permits slaveowners to kill rebellious slaves.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Lucy Terry, a slave, composes Bars Fight, the first known poem by an African American. A description of an Indian raid on Terry's hometown in Massachusetts, the poem will be passed down orally and published in 1855
subject: Enslaved People in Colonial America

events: Anthony Benezet persuades fellow Philadelphia Quakers to open the first free school for black children in the colonies.
subject: Black Education

events: Twenty-one year old Benjamin Banneker of Maryland constructs one of the first clocks in Colonial America, the first of a long line of inventions and innovations until his death in 1806.
subject: Free Blacks in Colonial America

events: The African Baptist or Bluestone Church is founded on the William Byrd plantation near the Bluestone River, in Mecklenburg, Virginia, becoming the first known black church in North America
subject: 18th Century Black Religion

events: A school for free black children is opened in Philadelphia.
subject: Black Education

events: Briton Hammon publishes A Narrative of the Uncommon Sufferings and Surprising Deliverance of Briton Hammon in Boston. This is believed to be the first autobiographical work written by an enslaved African living in British North America.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Jupiter Hammon, a Long Island enslaved person, publishes a book of poetry. This is believed to be the first volume of poetry written and published by an African American.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Virginia restricts voting rights to white men.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: On March 5, Crispus Attucks, an escaped slave of African and Native American ancestry, becomes the first Colonial resident to die for American independence when he is killed by the British in the Boston Massacre.
subject: American Revolution

events: Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral, written by Phillis Wheatley, an enslaved Bostonian, is published in that city. It is the first book written by an African American woman published in the United States and only the second book in the nation's history authored by a woman to be published.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The Silver Bluff Baptist Church, the oldest continuously operating black church, is founded in Silver Bluff, South Carolina near Savannah, Georgia.
subject: 18th Century Black Religion

events: A group of enslaved blacks petition the Massachusetts General Court (legislature) insisting they too have a natural right to their freedom.
subject: Emancipation

events: First African Baptist Church, one of the earliest black churches in the United States, is founded in Petersburg, Virginia.
subject: Africans in Colonial America

events: African Americans participate on the Patriot side in the earliest battles of the Revolution, Concord, Lexington and Bunker Hill. Two of the first of these Patriot soldiers were Peter Salem at the Battle of Concord and Salem Poor at the Battle of Bunker Hill.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: General George Washington reverses his earlier policy of rejecting the services of slaves and free blacks in the army. Five thousand African-Americans serve during the Revolutionary War including two predominantly black units in Massachusetts, one in Connecticut, one in Rhode Island.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: The Society for the Relief of Free Negroes Unlawfully held in Bondage holds the first of four meetings in Philadelphia on April 14. This is the first abolitionist meeting in North America. In 1784 the organization becomes the Pennsylvania Abolition Society with Benjamin Franklin as its first president.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: On Nov. 7, Lord Dunmore, British Governor of Virginia declares all slaves free who come to the defense of the British Crown against the Patriot forces. Dunmore eventually organizes the first regiment of black soldiers to fight under the British flag.
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: The American War of Independence. Approximately 450,000 enslaved Africans comprise 20% of the population of the colonies at the time of the Declaration of Independence.
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: A passage in the Declaration of Independence authored by Thomas Jefferson at the Continental Congress meeting in Philadelphia, condemned the slave trade.  The controversial passage is removed from the Declaration due to pressure from the southern colonies.
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: Approximately 100,000 enslaved people flee their masters during the Revolution.
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: On July 8, Vermont becomes the first political jurisdiction in the United States to abolish slavery.
subject: Emancipation

events: Boston businessman Paul Cuffe and his brother, John, refuse to pay taxes, claiming as blacks not allowed to vote they suffer taxation without representation.
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: The 1st Rhode Island Regiment comprised of enslaved and free black men is formed. It is the first and only all-black military unit to fight on the Patriot side in the American Revolution
subject: African Americans in the American Revolution

events: Massachusetts abolishes slavery and grants African American men the right to vote.
subject: Emancipation

events: The Free African Union Society is created in Newport, Rhode Island. It is the first cultural organization established by blacks in North America.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Pennsylvania adopts first gradual emancipation law. All children of enslaved people born after Nov. 1, 1780 will be free on their 28th birthday.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Paul Cuffee, a Boston merchant and shipowner, leads six other free blacks in petitioning the Massacusetts to end their taxation without representation.
subject: Free Blacks in Colonial America

events: Twenty thousand black loyalists depart with British Troops from the newly independent United States. Approximately 5,000 African Americans served with Patriot forces. Three times that many served with the British although not all of them leave the new nation.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Connecticut and Rhode Island adopt gradual emancipation laws.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Congress rejects Thomas Jefferson's proposal to exclude slavery from all western territories after 1800.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: Prince Hall establishes the first black Masonic lodge in the United States. African Lodge #459 is granted a Masonic charter by the Grand Lodge of England.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: The New York African Society, a spiritual and benevolent association, is created by free blacks in New York City.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: New York frees all slaves who served in the Revolutionary Army.
subject: Emancipation

events: The New York Society for the Promoting of the Manumission of Slaves is founded by prominent New Yorkers including John Jay and Alexander Hamilton.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: On July 13, Congress enacts the Northwest Ordinance, which establishes formal procedures for transforming territories into states. It provides for the eventual establishment of three to five states in the area north of the Ohio River, to be considered equal with the original 13. The Ordinance includes a Bill of Rights that guarantees freedom of religion, the right to trial by jury, public education and a ban on slavery in the region.
subject: Emancipation

events: The U.S. Constitution is drafted. It provides for the continuation of the slave trade for another 20 years and required states to aid slaveholders in the recovery of fugitive slaves. It also stipulates that a slave counts as three-fifths of a man for purposes of determining representation in the House of Representatives.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: Free blacks in New York City found the African Free School, where future leaders Henry Highland Garnett and Alexander Crummell are educated.
subject: Black Education

events: Richard Allen and Absalom Jones form the Free African Society in Philadelphia.
subject: Black Organizations

events: In Massachusetts, following an incident in which free blacks were kidnapped and transported to the state from the island of Martinique, the Massachusetts legislature declares the slave trade illegal and provides monetary damages to victims of kidnappings.
subject: Emancipation

events: Free African Americans in Charleston form the Brown Fellowship Society.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Census of 1790 (First Census of the U.S. Population): Total population, 3,929,214, Black Population: 757,208 (19.3%) including 59,150 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: In February Major Andrew Ellicott hires Benjamin Banneker to assist in a survey of the boundaries of the 100-square-mile federal district that would later become the District of Columbia.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: Benjamin Banneker's Almanac is published in Philadelphia. It is the first book of science published by an African American.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The United States Congress enacts the first Fugitive Slave Law. Providing assistance to fugitive slaves is now a criminal offense.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: Eli Whitney invents the cotton gin in Georgia which he patents on March 13.  The development of the cotton gin provides a major boost to the slave-based cotton economy of the South.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: Mother Bethel AME Church is established in Philadelphia by Richard Allen.
subject: 18th Century Black Religion

events: New York adopts a gradual emancipation law.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Bowdoin College is founded in Maine. It later becomes a center for Abolitionist activity; Gen. Oliver O. Howard (Howard University) graduated from the college; Harriet Beecher Stowe taught there and began to write Uncle Tom's Cabin while there (in 1850)
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: On August 23, The African Methodist Episcopal Church is organized in Philadelphia.
subject: 18th Century Black Religion

events: Joshua Johnston of Baltimore, Maryland becomes the first black portrait painter to gain widespread recognition in the United States
subject: Art and Literature

events: Venture Smith's A Narrative of the Life and Adventures of Venture, A Native of Africa But Resident Above Sixty Years in the United States of America appears as the first slave narrative written by the person in bondage. Earlier narratives were written by white authors as dictated by enslaved people.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On August 30, Gabriel Prosser attempts a slave rebellion in Richmond, Virginia.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: The United States Congress rejects 85 to 1 an antislavery petition offered by free Philadelphia African Americans.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: Census of 1800, U.S. Population: 5,308,483, Black Population: 1,002,037 (18.9%) including 108,435 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: The Ohio Constitution outlaws slavery. It also prohibits free blacks from voting.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: James Callender claims that Thomas Jefferson has for many years past kept, as his concubine, one of his own slaves, Sally Hemings. His charge is published in the Richmond Recorder that month, and the story is soon picked up by the Federalist press around the country.
subject: Black Women

events: On April 30, Louisiana is purchased from the French. The new territory nearly doubles the size of the United States.
subject: U.S. Expansion

events: Lemuel Haynes is the first African American to receive an honorary degree in U.S. history when Middlebury College awards him a Master's Degree at its second commencement.
subject: Humanitarian Honors

events: In 1804 the Ohio legislature passes the Ohio Black Codes and in doing so becomes the first non-slaveholding state to place restrictions exclusively on its African American residents.
subject: Racial Restrictions

events: The Lewis and Clark Expedition explores newly purchased Louisiana and the Pacific Northwest. An African American, York, is prominent in the expedition.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: New Jersey disfranchises black voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: The United States government abolishes the importation of enslaved Africans when it enacts the Slave Importation Ban.  The ban, however, is widely ignored. Between 1808 and 1860, approximately 250,000 blacks are illegally imported into the United States. Slave trading within the states (the domestic trade) continues until the end of the Civil War.
subject: The Slave Trade

events: New York recognizes marriage within the African American community.
subject: Family and Interpersonal Relationships

events: Census of 1810, U.S. Population: 7,239,881, Black Population: 1,377,808 (19 percent) including 186,446 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: The U.S. Congress prohibits African Americans from carrying mail for the U.S. Postal Service.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: By 1810, 75 percent of the African Americans in Delaware are free. This is the largest percentage of free blacks in a slave state.
subject: Emancipation

events: The African Insurance Company of Philadephia is the first black-owned insurance company in the United States.
subject: Black Business

events: Andry's Rebellion on January 8-11. A slave insurrection led by Charles Deslondes, begins on the Louisiana plantation of Manual Andry.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Previously independent African American schools become part of the Boston public school system.
subject: Black Education

events: Two African American regiments are formed in New York to fight in the War of 1812.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Six hundred African American troops are among the U.S. Army of 3,000 led by General Andrew Jackson which defeats British forces at the Battle of New Orleans. The black troops were led by Major Joseph Savary, the highest ranking black officer in the history of the U.S. Army.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Richard Allen officially creates the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the first wholly African American church denomination in the United States.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: Abolitionist Levi Coffin establishes the Underground Railroad in Indiana.  Eventually it will spread across the North with routes originating in the South and stretching to British Canada.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: The American Colonization Society is founded by Bushrod Washington (the nephew of George Washington) and other prominent white Americans who believe enslaved African Americans should be freed and settled in Africa.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Francis Johnson of Philadelphia becomes the first black bandleader and composer to publish sheet music. In 1837 he becomes the first American to perform before Queen Victoria in England.
subject: 19th Century Black Music

events: Escaped slaves from Georgia, South Carolina and Alabama join the military campaign of the Florida Seminoles to keep their homelands.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Connecticut disfranchises black voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: Thomas Day of North Carolina is considered the first widely known furniture and cabinet maker in the United States.
subject: Business and Labor

events: Census of 1820, U.S. Population: 9,638,452, Black Population: 1,771,656 (18.4 percent) including 233,504 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: The Compromise of 1820 allows Missouri into the Union as a slave state and Maine as a free state. It also sets the boundary between slave and free territory in the West at the 36th parallel.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: New York maintains property qualifications for African American male voters while abolishing the same for white male voters. Missouri disfranchises free black male voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: Thomas Jennings of New York City became the first African American to receive a patent from the United States government.  His patent came because he developed a process for dry cleaning clothes.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The African Grove Theater Group, the first black acting company, is founded in New York City.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Denmark Vesey is arrested for planning a slave rebellion in South Carolina.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Rhode Island disfranchises black voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: The African Grove Theater performs The Drama of King Shotaway, the first play written by an African American, Wiliam Henry Brown.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Freedom's Journal begins publication on March 16 in New York City as the first African American owned newspaper in the United States. The editors are John Russwurm and Samuel Cornish.
subject: The Black Press

events: Slavery is officially abolished in New York.
subject: Gradual Emancipation

events: Theodore Sedgewick Wright is the first black graduate of the Princeton Theological Seminary.
subject: Black Education

events: More than half of Cincinnati's African American residents are driven out of the city by white mob violence. The Cincinnati riots usher in a more than century-long period of white violence against Northern black urban communities.
subject: Racial Violence

events: David Walker of Boston publishes An Appeal to the Colored Citizens of the Worldwhich calls for a slave uprising in the South.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: The Oblate Sisters of Providence, the first permanent order of black Catholic nuns, is founded in Baltimore, Maryland.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: Census of 1830, U.S. Population: 12,866,020, Black Population: 2,328,842 (18.1 percent) including 319,599 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: African American delegates from New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and Virginia meet in Philadelphia in the first of a series of National Negro Conventions to devise ways to challenge slavery in the South and racial discrimination in the North.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: North Carolina enacts a statute that bans teaching slaves to read and write.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: Nat Turner leads a slave rebellion in Southampton, Virginia, killing at least 57 whites.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Alabama makes it illegal for enslaved or free blacks to preach.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: William Lloyd Garrison of Boston founds The Liberator, the first abolitionist newspaper in the United States.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: Jarena Lee's The Life and Religious Experience of Jarena Lee, A Coloured Lady, was the first autobiography by an African American woman.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Oberlin College is founded in Ohio. It admits African American men, black women and white women. By 1860 one third of its students are black.
subject: Black Education

events: The Female Anti-Slavery Society, the first African American women's abolitionist society, is founded in Salem, Massachusetts.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: The Georgia Infirmary, founded by white philanthropists in Savannah, is the first hospital in the United States dedicated to black patient care.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: The American Anti-Slavery Society is established in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: African Free Schools are incorporated into the New York Public School system.
subject: Black Education

events: Henry Blair of Maryland received a patent from the U.S. government for developing a mechanical corn planter.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: South Carolina bans the teaching of blacks, enslaved or free, in its borders.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: David Ruggles, abolitionist activist, opens the first African American bookstore in the nation, in New York City.
subject: Black Business

events: Texas declares its independence from Mexico. In its Constitution as an independent nation, Texas recognizes slavery and makes it difficult for free blacks to remain there.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: The Gag Rule prohibits Congress from considering petitions regarding slavery.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: The Institute for Colored Youth is founded in Southeastern Pennsylvania. It later becomes Cheyney University.
subject: Black Education

events: The Philadelphia Vigilence Committee is organized to help fugitive slaves escape their pursuers.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: Pennsylvania disfranchises black voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: On August 29, American vessels tow the Spanish ship the Amistad and its 53 slaves into New London, Connecticut. Their fate is decided by the United States Supreme Court in United States v. The Amistad on March 9, 1841 when the Court rules them free and they return to Africa.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Census of 1840, U.S. Population: 17,069,453, Black Population: 2,873,648 (16.1 percent) including 386,293 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: Frederick Douglass leads a successful campaign against Rhode Island's proposed Dorr Constitution which would continue the prohibition on black voting rights.
subject: Black Politics

events: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Prigg v. Pennsylvania that states did not have to offer aid in the hunting or recapture of fugitive slaves within their borders.
subject: Anti-Slavery Campaign

events: Rev. Henry Highland Garnet delivers his controversial "Address to the Slaves" at the National Negro Convention meeting in Buffalo, New York, which calls for a servile insurrection.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Sojourner Truth and William Wells Brown begin their campaigns against slavery.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: On June 25, the Legislative Committee of the Provisional Government of Oregon enacts the first of a series of black exclusion laws.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: Texas is annexed to the United States.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: Frederick Douglass publishes his autobiography, The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: Macon B. Allen of Worcester, Massachusetts is the first African American admitted to the bar in any state when he is allowed to practice law in Massachusetts.
subject: The Legal System

events: William Henry Lane (Master Juba) of New York City is the first acclaimed black dance performer.
subject: Dance and Theater

events: War with Mexico.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: Frederick Douglass begins publication of The North Star in Rochester, New York.
subject: The Black Press

events: Missouri bans the education of free blacks.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: Missouri abolitionists file a lawsuit on behalf of Dred Scott to gain his freedom. The case is eventually decided by the U.S. Supreme Court a decade later.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: David Jones Peck is the first African American graduate of a U.S. medical school. He graduates from Rush Medical College in Chicago.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On February 2 in the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, Mexico cedes California, Arizona, New Mexico, Nevada, and Utah and gives up claim to Texas at conclusion of War in exchange for $20 million.
subject: U.S. Expansion

events: On July 19-20, Frederick Douglass is among the handful of men who attend the first Women's Rights Convention at Seneca Falls, New York.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: The California Gold Rush begins. Eventually four thousand African Americans will migrate to California during this period.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: Harriett Tubman escapes from slavery and begins her efforts to rescue enslaved people.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: On December 4, Benjamin Roberts files a school desegregation lawsuit on behalf of his daughter, Sarah, who is denied admission to a Boston school. The lawsuit is unsuccessful.
subject: Black Education

events: Census of 1850, U.S. Population: 23,191,876, Black Population: 3,638,808 (15.7 percent) including 433,807 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: The Compromise of 1850 revisits the issue of slavery. California enters the Union as a free state, but the territories of New Mexico and Utah are allowed to decide whether they will enter the Union as slave or free states. The 1850 Compromise also allowed passage of a much stricter Fugitive Slave Law.
subject: The Slavery Contoversy

events: On August 27, Lucy Stanton of Cleveland completes the course requirements for Oberlin Collegiate Institute (now Oberlin College) and becomes the first African American woman to graduate from an American college or university.
subject: Black Education

events: The American League of Colored Workers, formed in New York City, is the first African American labor union in the United States.
subject: Black Labor

events: Sojourner Truth delivers her famous "Aren't I a Woman" speech at the Women's Rights Convention, Akron, Ohio on May 29.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: Harriet Beecher Stowe publishes her novel, Uncle Tom's Cabin, which becomes a best selling book and a major influence on the Anti-Slavery Movement.
subject: The Abolition Movement

events: Martin R. Delany publishes The Condition, Elevation, Emigration and Destiny of the Colored People of the United States.
subject: Free Blacks in Antebellum America

events: The Jackson Street Hospital in Augusta, Georgia is established as the second medical facility dedicated solely to the care of African American patients.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Elizabeth Taylor Greenfield (the Black Swan) debuts at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City and performs before Queen Victoria at Buckingham Palace a year later.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: William Wells Brown of Buffalo, New York, becomes the first African American novelist when he publishes Clotel, or the President's Daughter.  The novel is published in England, however and thus he is not considered the first published black novelist in the United States.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On May 24, Virginia fugitive slave Anthony Burns is captured in Boston and returned to slavery under the provisions of the Fugitive Slave Act. Fifty thousand Boston residents watch his transport through the streets of the city in shackles. A Boston church raises $1,500 to purchase his freedom and Burns returns to the city in 1855, a free man.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: On May 30, the Kansas-Nebraska Act is passed by Congress. The Act repeals the Missouri Compromise and permits the admission of Kansas and Nebraska Territories to the Union after their populations decide on slavery.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: The Republican Party is formed in Jackson, Michigan in the summer in opposition to the extension of slavery into the western territories.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: Bleeding Kansas is an outgrowth of the controversy over the Kansas-Nebraska Act. Between 1854 and 1858 armed groups of pro- and anti-slavery factions often funded and sponsored by organizations in the North and South, compete for control of Kansas Territory, initiating waves of violence that killed 55 people. Bleeding Kansas was seen as a preview of the U.S. Civil War.
subject: The Slavery Controversy

events: On October 13, Ashmun Institute, the first institution of higher learning for young black men, is founded by John Miller Dickey and his wife, Sarah Emlen Cresson. In 1866 it is renamed Lincoln University (Pa.) after President Abraham Lincoln
subject: Black Education

events: James A. Healy is ordained in France as the first black Jesuit priest. He becomes Bishop of Portland, Maine in 1875, a diocese that includes all of Maine and New Hampshire, and holds that post for 25 years.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: The Massachusetts Legislature outlaws racially segregated schools.
subject: Black Education

events: William C. Nell of Boston publishes The Colored Patriots of the American Revolution, considered the first history of African Americans.
subject: Art and Literature

events: In November, John Mercer Langston is elected town clerk of Brownhelm Township, Ohio, becoming the first black elected official in the state of Ohio.
subject: Black Politics

events: Frederick Douglass is nominated by the Liberty Party of New York for the office of secretary of state. He is the first black candidate in any state to be nominated for a statewide office.
subject: Black Politics

events: Wilberforce University becomes the first school of higher learning owned and operated by African Americans. It is founded by the African Methodist Episcopal Church. Bishop Daniel A. Payne becomes the institution's first president.
subject: Black Education

events: On March 6, the Dred Scott Decision is handed down by the U.S. Supreme Court.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Arkansas enslaves free blacks who refuse to leave the state.
subject: Antebellum Slavery

events: On October 16, John Brown leads twenty men, including five African Americans (John Copeland, Shields Green, Lewis S. Leary, Dangerfield Newby, and Osborne Anderson), in an unsuccessful attempt to seize the Federal Armory at Harpers Ferry, Virginia (now West Virginia) to inspire a servile insurrection.
subject: Resistance to Enslavement

events: Harriett Wilson of Milford, New Hampshire publishes Our Nig; or Sketches from the Life of a Free Black, the first novel by an African American woman.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Census of 1860, U.S. Population: 31,443,321, Black Population: 4,441,830 (14.1 percent) including 488,070 free African Americans.
subject: Black Population

events: On November 6, Abraham Lincoln is elected president.
subject: The Civil War

events: On December 20, South Carolina secedes from the Union.
subject: The Civil War

events: Congress passes the First Confiscation Act which prevents Confederate slave owners from reenslaving runaways.
subject: African Americans and the Civil War

events: On May 2, black men in New Orleans organize the First Louisiana Native Guard of the Confederate Army. In doing so they create the first and only military unit of black officers and enlisted men to pledge to fight for Southern independence. By February 1862, after New Orleans is occupied by Union forces, the Louisiana Native Guard becomes a military unit in the United States Army.
subject: Black Soldiers in the Civil War

events: By February, Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and Texas secede. They form the Confederate States of America on March 4. After the firing on Fort Sumter near Charleston, South Carolina on April 12, Virginia, Arkansas, Tennessee and North Carolina secede.
subject: The Civil War

events: The Civil War. Approximately 200,000 blacks (most are newly escaped/freed slaves) serve in Union armed forces and over 20,000 are killed in combat.
subject: African Americans in the Civil War

events: The Port Royal (South Carolina) Reconstruction Experiment begins in March.
subject: African Americans in the Civil War

events: On April 16, Congress abolishes slavery in the District of Columbia.
subject: Emancipation

events: In May the coastal pilot Robert Smalls escapes Charleston, South Carolina with The Planter, a Confederate vessel and sixteen enslaved people.
subject: African Americans in the Civil War

events: Congress permits the enlistment of African American soldiers in the U.S. Army on July 17.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: With the southern states absent from Congress, the body recognizes Haiti and Liberia, marking the first time diplomatic relations are established with predominately black nations.
subject: African Americans in the Civil War

events: On September 22, President Abraham Lincoln issues the Emancipation Proclamationand announces that it will go into effect on July 1, 1863 if the states then in rebellion have not by that point returned to the Union.
subject: Emancipation

events: Educator Mary Jane Patterson is generally recognized as the first African American woman to receive a B.A. degree when she graduated from Oberlin College in 1862.  Lucy Stanton Day Sessions graduated from Oberlin twelve years earlier but was not in a program that awarded official bachelor's degrees.
subject: Black Education

events: Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation takes effect on January 1, legally freeing slaves in areas of the South still in rebellion against the United States.
subject: Emancipation

events: The New York City draft riots erupt on July 13 and continue for four days, during which at least 100 of the city's residents are killed. This remains the highest death toll in any urban conflict in the 19th or 20th Centuries.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On July 18, the Fifty-Fourth Massachusetts Volunteers, the first officially recognized all-black military unit in the Union army, assaults Fort Wagner in Charleston, South Carolina in an unsuccessful effort to take the fortification. Sergeant William H. Carney becomes the first African American to receive the Congressional Medal of Honor for bravery under fire.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: Robert Smalls of Charleston, South Carolina, is the first and only African American to be commissioned a captain in the U.S. Navy during the Civil War.
subject: Black Soldiers in the Civil War

events: Susie King Taylor of Savannah is the first black Army nurse in U.S. history.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: The Fort Pillow Massacre takes place in West Tennessee on April 12. Approximately 300 of the 585 soldiers of the Union garrison at Fort Pillow are killed including many after the Union forces surrender. Only 14 Confederate soldiers die in the battle.
subject: Afrrican Americans in the Military

events: In June Dr. Rebecca Lee Crumpler of Boston is the first African American woman to earn a medical degree when she graduates from the New England Female Medical College in Boston.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On June 15, Congress passed a bill authorizing equal pay, equipment, arms, and health care for African American troops in the Union Army.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: On October 4, La Tribune de la Nouvelle Orleans (the New Orleans Tribune) begins publication. The Tribune is the first black-owned daily newspaper.
subject: The Black Press

events: On February 1, 1865, Abraham Lincoln signs the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution outlawing slavery throughout the United States.
subject: Reconstruction Amendments

events: On March 3, Congress established the Freedmen's Bureau to provide health care, education, and technical assistance to emancipated slaves. Congress also charters the Freedman's Bank to promote savings and thrift among the ex-slaves.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union General Ulysses S. Grant on April 9 at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, effectively ending the Civil War.
subject: The Civil War

events: On April 15, President Abraham Lincoln is assassinated by John Wilkes Booth in Washington, D.C.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: On June 19, enslaved African Americans in Texas finally receive news of their emancipation. From that point they commemorate that day as Juneteenth.
subject: Emancipation

events: Between September and November, a number of ex-Confederate states pass so called Black Codes.
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: The Ku Klux Klan is formed on December 24th in Pulaski, Tennessee by six educated, middle class former Confederate veterans.  The Klan soon adopts terror tactics to thwart the aspirations of the formerly enslaved and their supporters.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: Twenty thousand African American troops are among the 32,000 U.S. soldiers sent to the Rio Grande as a show of force against Emperor Maximilian's French troops occupying Mexico. Some discharged black soldiers join the forces of Mexican resistance leader Benito Juarez.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: John S. Rock is the first African American to argue a case before the U.S. Supreme Court.
subject: The Legal System

events: Martin R. Delany's appointment as Major by President Abraham Lincoln makes him the highest ranking African American officer during the Civil War.
subject: Black Soldiers in the Civil War

events: On January 16, General William T. Sherman issues Special Field Order No. 15 which gives 400,000 acres of abandoned coastal land in South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida to formerly enslaved people.  This order becomes the basis for subsequent "40 acres and a mule" demands by former slaves and their supporters.
subject: Reconstruction

events: With the approval of the Georgia Legislature on December 6, the 13th Amendmenttook effect and outlawed slavery throughout the United States and its possessions.
subject: Reconstruction Amendments

events: Fisk University is founded in Nashville, Tennessee on January 9.
subject: Black Education

events: On April 9, Congress overrides President Andrew Johnson's veto to enact the Civil Rights Act of 1866. The act confers citizenship upon black Americans and guarantees equal rights with whites.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: On May 1-3, white civilians and police in Memphis, Tennessee kill forty-six African Americans and injure many more, burning ninety houses, twelve schools, and four churches in what will be known as the Memphis Massacre.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On June 13, Congress approves the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution, guaranteeing due process and equal protection under the law to all citizens. The amendment also grants citizenship to African Americans.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: Congress authorizes the creation of four all-black regiments in the United States Army. Two cavalry regiments, the 9th and 10th and two infantry regiments, the 24th and 25th will become the first and only units in which black soldiers can serve until the Spanish American War. They will be known as Buffalo Soldiers.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Police in New Orleans supporting the Democratic Mayor storm a Republican meeting of blacks and whites on July 30, killing 34 black and 3 white Republicans. Over 150 people are injured in the attack.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On January 8, overriding President Andrew Johnson's veto, Congress grants the black citizens of the District of Columbia the right to vote. Two days later it passes the Territorial Suffrage Act which allows African Americans in the western territories to vote.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: Morehouse College is founded in Atlanta on February 14.
subject: Black Education

events: The Reconstruction Acts are passed by Congress on March 2. Congress divides ten of the eleven ex-Confederate states into military districts. These acts also reorganize post-war Southern governments, disfranchising former high ranking Confederates and enfranchising former slaves in the South.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: On March 2, Howard University is chartered by Congress in Washington, D.C. The institution is named after General Oliver O. Howard who heads the Freedman's Bureau.
subject: Black Education

events: On July 21, the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution is ratified, granting citizenship to any person born or naturalized in the United States.
subject: Reconstruction Amendments

events: Opelousas, Louisiana is the site of the Opelousas Massacre on September 28, in which an estimated 200 to 300 black Americans are killed by whites opposed to Reconstruction and African American voting.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On November 3, Civil War general Ulysses S. Grant (Republican) is elected president.
subject: Reconstruction

events: On November 3, John Willis Menard is elected to Congress from Louisiana's Second Congressional District. Menard is the first African American elected to Congress. However, neither he nor his opponent will be seated due to disputed election results.
subject: Black Politics

events: Howard University Medical School opens on November 9. It is the first medical school in the United States established for the training of African American doctors.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On February 26, Congress sends the Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution to the states for approval. The amendment guarantees African American males the right to vote.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: On April 6, Ebenezer Don Carlos Bassett is appointed minister to Haiti. He is the first black American diplomat and presidential appointee.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: Isaac Myers organizes the Colored National Labor Union in Baltimore.
subject: Black Labor

events: George Lewis Ruffin is the first African American to receive a law degree from any institution when he graduates from Harvard Law School.
subject: The Legal System

events: Census of 1870, U.S. population: 39,818,449, Black population: 4,880,009 (12.7 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: Hiram R. Revels (Republican) of Mississippi takes his seat in the U.S. Senate on February 25. He is the first black United States senator, though he serves only one year, completing the unexpired term of Jefferson Davis.
subject: Black Politics

events: The Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution is ratified on March 30.
subject: Reconstruction Amendments

events: In June Richard T. Greener becomes the first African American undergraduate to graduate from Harvard University.
subject: Black Education

events: The Preparatory High School for Colored Youth opens in Washington, D.C. It is the first public high school for African Americans in the nation. The institution is later named the M Street High School and finally Dunbar High School in honor of Paul Lawrence Dunbar.
subject: Black Education

events: In February Congress passes the Civil Rights Act of 1871 popularly known as the Ku Klux Klan Act.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: On October 6, Fisk University's Jubilee Singers begin their first national tour. The Jubilee Singers become world-famous singers of black spirituals, performing before the Queen of England and the Emperor of Japan. The money they earn finances the construction of Jubilee Hall on the Fisk University campus.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: George Washington, an early black settler in Washington Territory becomes the first African American to found a predominately white town when he establishes Centerville, later Centralia, Washington.
subject: Municipal Affairs

events: Lt. Governor Pinckney Benton Stewart Pinchback of Louisiana serves as governor of the state for one month from December 1872 to January 1873. He is the first African American to hold that position.
subject: Black Politics

events: Charlotte Ray of Washington, D.C. is the first African American woman and only the third woman admitted to the bar to practice law in the U.S.
subject: The Legal System

events: The 43rd Congress has seven black members.
subject: Black Politics

events: On April 14, the U.S Supreme Court in the Slaughterhouse Cases rules that the due process clause of the 14th Amendment protects national, not state, citizenship.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Bishop Patrick Healy serves as President of Georgetown University from 1873 to 1881. He is the first African American to preside over a predominately white university.
subject: Black Education

events: On Easter Sunday more than 100 African Americans were killed in northwest Louisiana while defending Republicans in local office against white militia. The incident became known as the Colfax Massacre. Later that year in what would be known as the Coushatta Massacre 30 people including white and black Republican officeholders and their supporters were killed by white militia.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The Freedman's Bank closes after African American depositors and investors lose more than one million dollars.
subject: Black Business

events: Federal troops are sent to Vicksburg, Mississippi in January to protect African Americans attempting to vote and to allow the safe return of the African American sheriff who had been forced to flee the city.
subject: African Americans and Reconstruction

events: On February 23rd Jim Crow laws are enacted in Tennessee. Similar statutes had existed in the North before the Civil War.
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: Congress enacts the Civil Rights Act of 1875 on March 1, guaranteeing equal rights to black Americans in public accommodations and jury duty.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: Blanche Kelso Bruce (Republican) of Mississippi becomes the first African American to serve a full six year term as senator when he takes his seat in the United States Senate on March 3.
subject: Black Politics

events: The 44th Congress has eight black members.
subject: Black Politics

events: Jockey Oliver Lewis wins the first Kentucky Derby race. Over the next 27 years fourteen black jockeys would ride the wining horse at the Derby.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Lewis H. Latimer, while working for the Boston patent attorney office of Crosby and Gould, assists Alexander Graham Bell in obtaining a patent for the telephone on March 7.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: In May, Edward Alexander Bouchet receives a Ph.D. from Yale University. He is the first African American to receive a Ph.D. from an American university and only the sixth American to earn a Ph.D. in physics.
subject: Black Education

events: Race riots and other forms of terrorism against black voters in South Carolina over the summer including the infamous Hamburg Massacre where blacks are killed while celebrating the Fourth of July, prompt President Grant to sent federal troops to restore order.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On October 13 Meharry Medical College is founded in Nashville by the Freedman's Aid Society of the Methodist Church.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: The presidential election of 1876, pitting Samuel Tilden (Democrat) against Rutherford B. Hayes (Republican), is inconclusive when the votes in the Electoral College are disputed.
subject: Reconstruction

events: The Compromise of 1877 (also known as the Wormley House Compromise because the meeting takes place in a black-owned hotel in Washington, D.C.) is an arrangement worked out in January of that year which effectively ends Reconstruction. Although Democratic Presidential candidate Samuel Tilden won the popular vote, Southern Democratic leaders agree to support Rutherford Hayes's efforts to obtain the disputed electoral votes of Florida, Louisiana and South Carolina in exchange for the withdrawal of the last federal troops from the South and the end of federal efforts to protect the civil rights of African Americans.
subject: Reconstruction

events: The 45th Congress has three black members.
subject: Black Politics

events: On June 15, Henry O. Flipper became the first African American to graduate from West Point.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: In July, 30 African American settlers from Kentucky establish the town of Nicodemus in western Kansas. This is the first of hundreds of all or mostly black towns created in the West.
subject: Black Settlement in the West

events: George Washington Henderson of the University of Vermont is the first African American elected to Phi Beta Kappy, the oldest humanities honor society in the U.S.
subject: Black Education

events: President Rutherford B. Hayes appoints Frederick Douglass as the first black U.S. Marshal. His jurisdication is the District of Columbia.
subject: Pre-1970 Politics

events: Marie Selika Williams becomes the first African American woman entertainer to perform at the White House when she presents a musical program to President Rutherford B. Hayes and assembled guests.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: Mary Eliza Mahoney becomes the first African American professional nurse, graduating from the New England Hospital for Women and Children in Boston.
subject: Blacks in the Professions

events: Approximately six thousand African Americans leave Louisiana and Mississippi counties along the Mississippi River for Kansas in what will be known as the Exodus.Henry Adams and Benjamin "Pap" Singleton were two of the major leaders of the Exodus.
subject: Black Settlement in the West

events: Census of 1880, U.S. population: 50,155,783, Black population: 6,580,793 (13.1 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: On May 14, Sgt. George Jordan of the Ninth Cavalry, commanding a detachment of Buffalo Soldiers, leads a successful defense of Tularosa, New Mexico Territory, against Apache Indians.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The U.S. Supreme Court in Strauder v. West Virginia rules that African Americans cannot be excluded from juries solely on the basis of race.
subject: Civil Rights

events: In January the Tennessee State Legislature votes to segregate railroad passenger cars. Tennessee's action is followed by Florida (1887), Mississippi (1888), Texas (1889), Louisiana (1890), Alabama, Kentucky, Arkansas, and Georgia (1891), South Carolina (1898), North Carolina (1899), Virginia (1900), Maryland (1904), and Oklahoma (1907).
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: Spelman College, the first college for black women in the U.S., is founded on April 11 by Sophia B. Packard and Harriet E. Giles.
subject: Black Education

events: On the Fourth of July 25-year-old Booker T. Washington opens Tuskegee Institute in central Alabama.
subject: Black Education

events: The Virginia State Assembly established the first state mental hospital for African Americans and locates it near Petersburg.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: George Washington Williams's History of the Negro Race in America from 1619 to 1880 is considered teh first history of African Americans that met the standards of professionally written history of that era.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The 50th Congress has no black members. Intimidation keeps most black voters from the polls.
subject: Black Politics

events: On October 16, U. S. Supreme Court in a decision known as the Civil Rights Casesdeclares invalid the Civil Rights Act of 1875, stating the Federal Government cannot bar corporations or individuals from discriminating on the basis of race.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On November 3, white conservatives in Danville, Virginia, seize control of the local racially integrated and popularly elected government, killing four African Americans in the process.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Judy W. Reed of Washington D.C. becomes the first African American woman to receive a patent. She is granted patent number 305,474 on September 23 for her creation of a dough kneader and roller.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: Granville Woods founds the Woods Railway Telegraph Company in Columbus, Ohio. The company manufactured and sold telephone and telegraph equipment.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On June 25, African American Priest Samuel David Ferguson is ordained a bishop of the Episcopal Church at a ceremony at Grace Church, New York City.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: The Knights of Labor, founded and headquartered in Philadelphia, reaches it peak membership of 700,000 with approximately 75,000 African American members.
subject: Black Labor

events: The American Federation of Labor is organized on December 8 in Columbus, Ohio. All major unions of the federation excluded black workers.
subject: Black Labor

events: Norris Wright Cuney becomes chairman of the Texas Republican Party. He is the first African American to head a major political party at the state level in U.S. history
subject: Pre-1970 Politics

events: On July 14, 1887, the directors of the International League (Major League Baseball) voted to prohibit the signing of additional black players while allowing those under contract such as Frank Grant of Buffalo and Moses Fleetwood Walker of Syracuse franchise, to remain with their teams through the 1888 season.  By 1889 blacks were no longer players in Major League Baseball.
subject: African American Athletes

events: The National Colored Farmers' Alliance is formed in Houston County, Texas.
subject: Black Farmers

events: On April 11, Edward Park Duplex is elected mayor of Wheatland, California. He is believed to be the first African American mayor of a predominantly white town in the United States.
subject: Black Politics

events: Two of America's first black-owned banks, the Savings Bank of the Grand Fountain United Order of the Reformers, in Richmond, Virginia, and Capital Savings Bank of Washington, D.C, open their doors.
subject: Black Business

events: Florida becomes the first state to use the poll tax to disenfranchise black voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: Frederick Douglass is appointed Minister to Haiti.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: Census of 1890, U.S. population: 62,947,714, Black population: 7,488,676 (11.9 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: The Afro-American League is founded on January 25 in Chicago under the leadership of Timothy Thomas Fortune.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On November 1, the Mississippi Legislature approves a new state Constitution that disenfranchises virtually all of the state's African American voters. The Mississippi Plan used literacy and understanding tests to prevent African Americans from casting ballots. Similar statutes were adopted by South Carolina (1895), Louisiana (1898), North Carolina (1900), Alabama (1901), Virginia (1901), Georgia (1908), and Oklahoma (1910).
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: William Henry Lewis and William Tecumseh Sherman Jackson were the first known black players on a white college football team when they played at Amherst College in Massachusetts. Lewis was team captain for the 1891-92 season.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Dr. Daniel Hale Williams founds Provident Hospital in Chicago, the first African American-owned hospital in the nation.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On June 15 operatic soprano Sissieretta Jones becomes the first African American to perform at Carnegie Hall.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On July 14 three companies of the 24th Infantry occupy the Coeur d'Alene Mining District in northern Idaho which has been declared under martial law following a violent strike by silver miners. They remain for four months.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: In October activist Ida B. Wells begins her anti-lynching campaign with the publication of Southern Horrors: Lynch Law and in All Its Phases and a speech in New York City's Lyric Hall
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: The National Medical Association is formed in Atlanta by African American physicians because they are barred from the American Medical Association.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: First intercollegiate football game between African American colleges takes place between Biddle University (now Johnson C. Smith University) and Livingston College.
subject: African American Athletes

events: A record 230 people are lynched in the United States this year, 161 are black and 69 white. In the period between 1882 and 1951, Tuskegee Institute compiled nationwide lynching statistics. In that 69 year period, 4,730 people were lynched including 3,437 blacks and 1,293 whites. Ninety-two women were victims of lynching, 76 were black and 16 were white. Although southern states accounted for 90 percent of the lynchings, every state in the continental U.S., with the exception of Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Hampshire and Vermont, reported lynching deaths sometime during the 69 year period.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The Baltimore Afro-American newspaper is founded by former slave John H. Murphy, Sr.
subject: The Black Press

events: Dr. Daniel Hale Williams performs the first successful operation on a human heart in his Chicago hospital. The patient, a victim of a chest stab wound, survives and lives for twenty years after the operation.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: The Church of God in Christ is founded in Memphis by Bishop Charles Harrison Mason.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: White terrorists attack black workers in New Orleans on March 11-12. Six blacks are killed.
subject: Racial Violence

events: In June, W.E.B. Du Bois becomes the first African American to receive a Ph.D. from Harvard University.
subject: Black Education

events: Booker T. Washington delivers his famous Atlanta Compromise address on September 18 at the Atlanta Cotton States Exposition. He says the Negro problem would be solved by a policy of gradualism and accommodation.
subject: Segregated America

events: Three black Baptist organizations, the Foreign Mission Baptist Convention of the United States (1880), the American National Baptist Convention (1886) and the Baptist National Educational Convention (1893) combined at Friendship Baptist Church in Atlanta to form the National Baptist Convention of America, Inc. The National Baptist Convention is the largest black religious denomination in the United States.
subject: 19th Century Black Religion

events: Plessey v. Ferguson is decided on May 18 when the U.S. Supreme Court rules that Southern segregation laws and practices (Jim Crow) do not conflict with the 13th and 14th Amendments. The Court defends its ruling by articulating the separate but equal doctrine.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On July 21 the National Association of Colored Women is formed in Washington, D.C. Mary Church Terrell is chosen as its first president.
subject: Black Organizations

events: In September George Washington Carver is appointed director of agricultural research at Tuskegee Institute. His work advances peanut, sweet potato, and soybean farming.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: John Shippen became the first black professional golfer when he participated in a tournament in England.
subject: African American Athletes

events: The American Negro Academy is established on March 5 in Washington, D.C. to encourage African American participation in art, literature and philosophy.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The first Phillis Wheatley Home is founded in Detroit. These homes, established in most cities with large African American populations, provide temporary accommodations and social services for single African American women.
subject: Black Organizations

events: In January the Louisiana Legislature introduces the Grandfather Clause into the state's constitution. Only males whose fathers or grandfathers were qualified to vote on January 1, 1867, are automatically registered. Others (African Americans) must comply with educational or property requirements.
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: The Spanish-American War begins on April 21. Sixteen regiments of black volunteers are recruited; four see combat in Cuba and the Philippines Five African Americans win Congressional Medals of Honor during the war. A number of black officers command troops for the first time.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The National Afro-American Council is founded on September 15 in Rochester, New York. The organization elects Bishop Alexander Walters as its first president.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On November 10, in Wilmington, North Carolina, eight black Americans were killed as white conservative Democrats forcibly removed from power black and white Republican officeholders in the city.  The episode would be known as the Wilmington Riot.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The North Carolina Mutual and Provident Insurance Company of Durham, North Carolina and the National Benefit Life Insurance Company of Washington, D.C. are established.
subject: Black Business

events: The U.S. Supreme Court in Williams v. Mississippi upholds the provisions of the Mississippi Constitution of 1890 which effectively disfranchises virtually all of the black voters in the state.
subject: Civil Rights

events: In May, the 24th Infantry returns to occupy the Coeur d'Alene Mining District in northern Idaho after violence again erupts.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The Afro-American Council designates June 4 as a national day of fasting to protest lynching and massacres.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Scott Joplin composes the Maple Leaf Rag, which introduces ragtime music to the United States.
