subject: 19th Century Black Music

events: Census of 1900, U.S. population: 75,994,575, Black population: 8,833,994 (11.6 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: In January James Weldon Johnson writes the lyrics and his brother John Rosamond Johnson composes the music for Lift Every Voice and Sing in their hometown of Jacksonville, Florida in celebration of the birthday of Abraham Lincoln. The song is eventually adopted as the black national anthem.
subject: 19th Century Black Music

events: The New Orleans Race Riot (also known as the Robert Charles Riot) erupts on July 23 and lasts four days. Twelve African Americans and seven whites were killed.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On August 23, the National Negro Business League is founded in Boston by Booker T. Washington to promote business enterprise.
subject: Black Business

events: In September Nannie Helen Burroughs leads the founding of the Women's' Convention of the National Baptist Convention at its meeting in Richmond, Virginia.
subject: Black Organizations

events: This year marks the beginning of significant West Indian immigration to the United States.
subject: Black Immigrants

events: By 1900 nearly two-thirds of the landowners in the Mississippi Delta were black farmers, most of whom had bought and cleared land after the Civil War.
subject: African American Farmers

events: An estimated 30,000 black teachers have been trained since the end of the U.S. Civil War in 1865. They are a major factor in helping more than half the black population achieve literacy by this date.
subject: Black Education

events: The last African American congressman elected in the 19th Century, George H. White, Republican of North Carolina, leaves office. No African American will serve in Congress for the next 28 years.
subject: Black Politics

events: On October 11, when Bert Williams and George Walker record their music for the Victor Talking Machine Company, they become the first African American recording artists.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On October 16, only one month after becoming President, Theodore Roosevelt holds an afternoon meeting at the White House with Booker T. Washington. At the end of the meeting the President informally invites Washington to remain for dinner, making the Tuskegee educator the first black American to dine at the White House with a president. Roosevelts casual act generates a national furor.
subject: Segregated America

events: Booker T. Washington's autobiography Up From Slavery is published.
subject: Art and Literature

events: In May jockey Jimmy Winkfield wins the Kentucky Derby in an era when African American jockeys dominate the sport.
subject: African American Athletes

events: W.E.B. Du Bois's The Souls of Black Folks is published on April 27. In it Du Bois rejects the gradualism of Booker T. Washington, calling for agitation on behalf of African American rights.
subject: Segregated America

events: Maggie Lena Walker founds St. Lukes Penny Savings Bank in Richmond, Virginia.
subject: Black Business

events: Educator Mary McLeod Bethune founds a college in Daytona Beach, Florida that today is known as Bethune-Cookman University.
subject: Black Education

events: Sigma Pi Phi (the Boule) is founded in Philadelphia on May 15 by four wealthy African American college graduates.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Dr. Solomon Carter Fuller, who trains at the Royal Psychiatric Hospital at the University of Munich with Dr. Alois Alzheimer, becomes a widely published pioneer in Alzheimers disease research. Fuller also becomes the nations first black psychiatrist.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: The black weekly newspaper, The Chicago Defender, is founded by Robert Abbotton May 5.
subject: The Black Press

events: The Niagara Movement is created on July 11-13, by African American intellectuals and activists, led by W.E.B. Du Bois and William Monroe Trotter.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Nashville African Americans boycott streetcars to protest racial segregation.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: The Azusa Street Revival begins in the former African Methodist Episcopal Church building at 312 Azusa Street in Los Angeles in April. The revival, led by black evangelist William J. Seymour, is considered the beginning of the worldwide Pentecostal Movement.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: On August 13 in Brownsville, Texas, approximately a dozen black troops riot against segregation and in the process kill a local citizen. When the identity of the killer cannot be determined, President Theodore Roosevelt discharges three companies of black soldiers on November 6.The episode would be called the Brownsville Affray.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The Atlanta Race Riot on September 22-24 produces twelve deaths; ten blacks and two whites.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On December 4, seven students at Cornell University form Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, the first college fraternity for black men.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Alain Locke of Philadelphia, a Harvard graduate, becomes the first African American Rhodes Scholar.
subject: Black Education

events: The Pittsburgh Courier is established by Edwin Harleston, a security guard and aspiring writer. Three years later attorney Robert Vann takes control of the paper as its editor-publisher.
subject: The Black Press

events: Madam C.J. Walker of Denver develops and markets her hair straightening method and creates one of the most successful cosmetics firms in the nation.
subject: Black Business

events: On January 15, Alpha Kappa Alpha, the first black sorority, is founded on the campus of Howard University.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On August 14, the Springfield Race Riot breaks out in Springfield, Illinois, the home town of Abraham Lincoln. Two blacks and four whites are killed. This is the first major riot in a Northern city in nearly half a century.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) is formed on February 12 in New York City, partly in response to the Springfield Riot.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On April 6, Admiral Robert E. Peary and African American Matthew Henson, accompanied by four Eskimos, become the first men known to have reached the North Pole.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On December 4, the New York Amsterdam News begins publication.
subject: The Black Press

events: The Knights of Peter Claver, the first permanent national black Catholic fraternal order, is founded in Mobile, Alabama.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Census of 1910: U.S. population: 93,402,151, Black population: 9,827,763 (10.7 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: The National Urban League is founded in New York City on September 29. The League is organized to help African Americans secure employment and to adjust to urban life.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The first issue of Crisis, the official publication of the NAACP, appears on November 1. W.E.B. Du Bois is the first editor.
subject: The Black Press

events: On December 19, the City Council of Baltimore approves an ordinance segregating black and white neighborhoods. This ordinance is followed by similar statutes in Dallas, Texas, Greensboro, North Carolina, Louisville, Kentucky, Norfolk, Virginia, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, Richmond, Virginia, Roanoke, Virginia, and St. Louis, Missouri.
subject: Jim Crow Legislation

events: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity is founded at Indiana University on January 5.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity is founded at Howard University on November 17.
subject: Black Organizations

events: W.C. Handy published "Memphis Blues" sheet music in Memphis
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: The Jubilee year, the 50th anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, is celebrated throughout the nation over the entire year.
subject: Black Holidays and Celebrations

events: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority is founded at Howard University on January 13.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On April 11, the Woodrow Wilson administration initiates the racial segregation of work places, rest rooms and lunch rooms in all federal offices across the nation.
subject: Segregated America

events: Bert Williams plays the lead role in Darktown Jubilee, making him the first African American actor to star in a motion picture.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: Noble Drew Ali founds the Moorish Science Temple in Newark, New Jersey.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity is founded at Howard University on January 9.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Cleveland inventor Garrett Morgan patents a gas mask called the Safety Hood and Smoke Protector. The mask, initially used to rescue trapped miners, is eventually adopted by the U.S. Army.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On August 1, World War I began in Europe.
subject: African Americans in World War I

events: The Great Migration of African Americans from the South to Northern cities begins.
subject: Black Migration

events: On June 21, the Oklahoma Grandfather Clause is overturned in Guinn v. United States.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: In September, Carter G. Woodson founds the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History (ASNLH) in Chicago.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Marcus Garvey founds the New York Division of the Universal Negro Improvement Association with sixteen members. Four years later the UNIA holds its national convention in Harlem. At its height the organization claims nearly two million members.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On July 25, Garrett Morgan uses his newly invented gas mask to rescue men trapped after an explosion in a tunnel 250 feet beneath Lake Erie.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: In January the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History (ASNLH) begins publishing the Journal of Negro History which becomes the first scholarly journal devoted to the study of African American history.
subject: Black Education

events: The United States enters World War I on April 6. Some 370,000 African-Americans join the armed forces with more than half serving in the French war zone. Over 1,000 black officers command these troops. The French government awards the Croix de Guerre to 107 African American soldiers.
subject: African Americans in World War I

events: The East St. Louis Race Riot begins on July 1 and continues to July 3. Forty people are killed, hundreds more injured, and 6,000 driven from their homes.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Nearly 10,000 African Americans and their supporters march down Manhattan's Fifth Avenue on July 28 as part of a silent parade, an NAACP-organized protest against lynchings, race riots, and the denial of rights. This is the first major civil rights demonstration in the 20th Century.
subject: Racial Violence

events: In August, A. Philip Randolph and Chandler Owen found The Messenger, a black socialist magazine, in New York City.
subject: The Black Press

events: On August 23, the Houston Mutiny and subsequent riot erupts between black soldiers and white citizens; two blacks and 11 whites are killed. Twenty-nine black soldiers are executed for participation in the riot.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On November 5, the Supreme Court in Buchanan v. Warley strikes down the Louisville, Kentucky ordinance mandating segregated neighborhoods.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On July 25-28, a race riot in Chester, Pennsylvania claims five lives, three blacks and two whites.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On July 26-29, in nearby Philadelphia, another race riot breaks out killing four, three blacks and one white.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The Armistice on November 11 ends World War I. However, the northern migration of African Americans continues. By 1930 there were 1,035,000 more black Americans in the North than in 1910.
subject: Black Migration

events: The Ku Klux Klan is revived in 1915 at Stone Mountain, Georgia, and by the beginning of 1919 operates in 27 states. Eighty-three African Americans are lynched during the year, among them a number of returning soldiers still in uniform.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The West Virginia State Supreme Court rules that an African American is denied equal protection under the law if his jury has no black members.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: The Associated Negro Press is established in Chicago by Claude A. Barnett on March 2.
subject: The Black Press

events: The twenty five race riots that take place throughout the nation prompt the term, Red Summer. The largest clashes take place on May 10 in Charleston, South Carolina, July 13 in Longview, Texas, July 19-23 in Washington, D. C, July 27-Aug. 1 in Chicago, September 28 in Omaha, and October 1-3 in Elaine, Arkansas.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Claude McKay publishes "If We Must Die," considered one of the first major examples of Harlem Renaissance writing.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Father Divine founds the Peace Mission Movement at his home in Sayville, New York.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: South Dakota resident Oscar Micheaux releases his first film, The Homesteader, in Chicago. Over the next four decades Micheaux will produce and direct 24 silent films and 19 sound films, making him the most prolific black filmmaker of the 20th Century.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: Census of 1920, Black population: 10,463,131 (9.9 percent), U.S. population: 105,710,620
subject: Black Population

events: The decade of the 1920s witnesses the Harlem Renaissance, a remarkable period of creativity for black writers, poets, and artists, including among others Claude McKay, Jean Toomer, Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On January 16, Zeta Phi Beta Sorority is founded at Howard University.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Andrew Rube Foster leads the effort to establish the Negro National (Baseball) League on February 14 in Kansas City. Eight teams are part of the league.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On August 26, the 19th Amendment to the Constitution is ratified giving all women the right to vote. Nonetheless, African American women, like African American men, are denied the franchise in most Southern states.
subject: Black Women

events: Former heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson opens the Club Deluxe in Harlem. Two years later gangaster Owney Madden buys the club and changes its name to the Cotton Club.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: Marcus Garvey leads the first international convention of the Universal Negro Improvement Association which he calls the International Convention of Negro Peoples of the World. The meeting is held at Madison Square Garden in New York City.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: Shuffle Along by Noble Sissle and Eubie Blake opens on Broadway on May 23. This is the first major play of the Harlem Renaissance.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On May 31-June 1, at least 60 blacks and 21 whites are killed in the Tulsa Race Riot in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The violence destroys a thriving African American neighborhood and business district called Deep Greenwood.
subject: Racial Violence

events: In June Sadie Tanner Mossell Alexander of the University of Pennsylvania, Eva B. Dykes of Radcliff and Georgiana R. Simpson of the University of Chicago become the first African American women to earn Ph.D. degrees.
subject: Black Education

events: Harry Pace forms Black Swan Phonograph Corporation, the first African American-owned record company in Harlem. His artists will include Mamie and Bessie Smith.
subject: Black Business

events: One of the earliest exhibitions of work by African American artists, including Henry Ossawa Tanner and Meta Vaux Warrick Fuller, is held at the 135th Street branch of the New York Public Library.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Jesse Binga founds the Binga State Bank in Chicago. It will become the largest African American bank in the nation before it collapses during the 1929 Stock Market Crash.
subject: Black Business

events: In September William Leo Hansberry of Howard University teaches the first course in African history and civilization at an American university.
subject: Black Education

events: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority is founded on November 12 in Indianapolis, Indiana.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The Harmon Foundation is established in New York City to promote African American participation in the fine arts.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On January 4, the small, predominately black town of Rosewood, Florida is destroyed by a mob of white residents from nearby communities.  The attack would be known as the Rosewood Massacre.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Marcus Garvey is imprisoned for mail fraud. He is sent to the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta in 1925.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: In September, the Cotton Club opens in Harlem.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: Bessie Smith signs with Columbia Records to produce race records. Her recording, "Down-Hearted Blues," becomes the first million-selling record by an African American artist. Two years later she records "St. Louis Blues" with Louis Armstrong.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: On November 20, Garrett T. Morgan patents a caution light which improves the traffic signal.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The National Urban League publishes its first issue of Opportunity, A Journal of Negro Life. The magazine, edited by Charles S. Johnson, quickly becomes a forum for artists and authors of the Harlem Renaissance.
subject: The Black Press

events: Rojo Jack is the first African American to particiapte in professional car racing when he competes in a race in Honolulu Hawaii.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Photographer James Van Der Zee begins his career by capturing images of Marcus Garvey and the UNIA.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The New Negro by Alain Locke is published in New York City.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The National Bar Association, an organization of black attorneys, is established on August 1 in Des Moines, Iowa.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On August 2, the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and Maids is organized with A. Philip Randolph as its first president.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On September 9, Ossian Sweet, a Detroit physician, is arrested for murder after he and his family kill a member of a white mob while defending their home. The Sweet family is represented at their trial by Clarence Darrow and acquitted of the charge.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The American Negro Labor Congress is founded in Chicago in October.
subject: Blacks and Organized Labor

events: Although African Americans have been serving as U.S. ambassadors since 1869, Clifton Reginald Wharton becomes the first African American to permanently enter the U.S. Foreign Service.
subject: International Diplomacy

events: Carter G. Woodson establishes Negro History Week in February between the Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass Birthdays.
subject: Black Holidays and Celebrations

events: Dr. Mordecai Johnson becomes the first African American president of Howard University in September.
subject: Black Education

events: The Carnegie Corporation purchases Arturo Schomburg's collection of books and artifacts on African American life. The collection becomes the basis for the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in New York City.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Chicago businessman Abe Saperstein forms the Harlem Globetrotters basketball team in Chicago on January 30.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On December 2, Marcus Garvey is deported from the United States.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: Floyd Joseph Calvin, a Pittsburgh Courier journalist, becomes the first black radio talk show host when he begins broadcasting from WGBS in Pittsburgh.
subject: Radio and Television

events: On November 6, Oscar DePriest, a Republican, is elected to Congress from Chicagos South Side. He is the first African American to represent a northern, urban district.
subject: Black Politics

events: The Atlanta Daily World begins publication in November.
subject: The Black Press

events: Fats Waller's musical, Aint Misbehavin, opens on Broadway.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: Census of 1930, Black population: 11,891,143 (9.7 percent), U.S. population: 122,775,046
subject: Black Population

events: James V. Herring establishes the Howard University Gallery of Art, the first gallery in the United States directed and controlled by African Americans. It is also one of the earliest galleries to highlight African American art.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Wallace Fard Muhammad founds Black Muslim movement in Detroit in 1930. Four years later Elijah Muhammad assumes control of the movement and transfers the headquarters to Chicago.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Walter White is named NAACP executive secretary. Soon afterwards the NAACP mounts a new strategy primarily using lawsuits to end racial discrimination.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: The Scottsboro Boys are arrested in Alabama. Their trial begins on April 6.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: William Grant Still becomes the first black symphony composer to have his music performed by a major symphony orchestra when the Rochester, New York, Philharmonic Orchestra presets "The Afro-American Symphony" in concert.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: The Tuskegee Syphilis Experiment begins under the direction of the U.S. Public Health Service. The experiment ends in 1972.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Gospel Composer Thomas Dorsey writes "Take My Hand, Precious Lord."
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: Franklin Delano Roosevelt is elected president of the United States in November.
subject: Blacks and the Great Depression

events: The Los Angeles Sentinel is founded by Leon H. Washington.
subject: The Black Press

events: Dudley Murphy releases the film The Emperor Jones starring Paul Robeson.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: W.E.B. Du Bois resigns from the NAACP in a dispute over the strategy of the organization in its campaign against racial discrimination. Roy Wilkins becomes the new editor of Crisis magazine.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: The Southern Tenant Farmers Union is organized by the Socialist Party.
subject: Racial Alliances

events: Zora Neale Hurston's first novel, Jonahs Gourd Vine, is published.
subject: Art and Literature

events: After operating under a number of names, the Apollo Theater opens under its current name in Harlem.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On March 20, the Harlem Race Riot, a one day riot erupts leaving two people dead.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On April 1, the U.S. Supreme Court rules in Norris v. Alabama that a defendant has a right to trial by a jury of his or her peers.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: The Michigan Chronicle is founded in Detroit by Louis E. Martin.
subject: The Black Press

events: On November 5, the Maryland Supreme Court rules in Murray v. Pearson that the University of Maryland must admit African Americans to its law school or establish a separate school for blacks. The University of Maryland chooses to admit its first black students.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On December 24, Mary McLeod Bethune calls together the leaders of 28 national womens organizations to found the National Council of Negro Women in New York City.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The first meeting of the National Negro Congress takes place in Chicago on February 14, 1936. Nearly 600 black organizations are represented.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On June 24, Mary McLeod Bethune is named Director of the Division of Negro Affairs, the National Youth Administration. She is the highest ranking black official in the Roosevelt Administration and leads the Black Cabinet. She is also the first black woman to receive a presidential appointment.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: Track star Jesse Owens wins four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics between August 3 and August 9.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Dr. William Augustus Hinton's book, Syphilis and Its Treatment, is the first published medical textbook written by an African American.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: William H. Hastie, former advisor to President Franklin Roosevelt, is confirmed on March 26 as the first black federal judge after his appointment by Roosevelt to the federal bench in the Virgin Islands.
subject: Judicial Appointments

events: The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and Maids is recognized by the Pullman Company.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On June 22, boxer Joe Louis wins the heavyweight championship in a bout with James J. Braddock in Chicago.
subject: African American Athletes

events: In October, Katherine Dunham forms the Negro Dance Group, a company of black artists dedicated to presenting aspects of African American and African-Caribbean Dance. The company eventually becomes the Katherine Dunham Group.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Hugh Morris Gloster founds the College Language Association (CLA) in Atlanta, Georgia.
subject: Black Education

events: On June 22, Joe Louis beats Max Schmeling in a rematch of his 1936 defeat by the German boxer.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Jacob Lawrence holds his first solo exhibition at the Harlem YMCA and completes his Toussaint L'Overture series.
subject: Art and Literature

events: In November Crystal Bird Fauset of Philadelphia becomes the first African American woman elected to a state legislature when she is chosen to serve in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives.
subject: Black Politics

events: On December 12, the U.S. Supreme Court in Missouri ex rel. Gaines v. Canadarules that a state that provides in-state education for whites must provide comparable in-state education for blacks.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Popular contralto Marian Anderson sings at Lincoln Memorial before 75,000 people on Easter Sunday after the Daughters of the American Revolution refuse to allow her to perform at Constitution Hall.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Bill Bojangles Robinson organizes the Black Actors Guild.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: World War II begins in Europe on September 1 when Germany invades Poland
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: Jane M. Bolin becomes the first African American woman judge in the United States when she is appointed to the domestic relations court of New York City.
subject: Judicial Appointments

events: Census of 1940, U.S. population 131,669,275, Black population: 12,865,518 (9.8 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: On February 29, Hattie McDaniel receives an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress in her role in Gone With the Wind. She becomes the first black actor to win an academy award.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: Richard Wright publishes his first novel, Native Son.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Dr. Charles R. Drew presents his thesis, Banked Blood at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. The thesis includes his research which discovers that plasma can replace whole blood transfusions.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: In October, Benjamin Oliver Davis, Sr., is named the first African American general in the regular army.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The NAACP Legal Defense Fund is established in New York City.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Mary Lucinda Dawson founds the National Negro Opera Company in Pittsburgh.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The U.S. Army creates the Tuskegee Air Squadron who will soon be known as the Tuskegee Airmen.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On June 25, President Franklin Roosevelt issues Executive Order 8802, desegregating war production plants and creating the Fair Employment Practices Committee (FEPC).
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: On December 8, the United States enters World War II following the attack on Pearl Harbor. Dorris "Dorie" Miller is later awarded the Navy Cross for his heroism during that battle.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: The desperate need for factory labor to build the war machine needed to win World War II leads to an unprecedented migration of African Americans from the South to the North and West. This migration transforms American politics as blacks increasingly vote in their new homes and put pressure on Congress to protect civil rights throughout the nation. Their activism lays much of the foundation for the national Civil Rights Movement a decade later.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: While teaching at Livingstone College in North Carolina, Margaret Walker publishes For My People, which she began as her master's thesis at the University of Iowa.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) is founded in Chicago by James Farmer, Jr., George Houser, Bernice Fisher, James Russell Robinson, Joe Guinn, and Homer Jack.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The U.S. Marine Corps accepts African American men for the first time at a segregated training facility at Camp Montford Point, North Carolina.  They will be known as the Montford Point Marines.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Charity Adams Earley becomes the first black woman commissioned officer in the Womens Army Auxiliary Corps (WAACs) while serving at Fort Des Moines.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Hugh Mulzac becomes the first African American captain in the American Merchant Marine.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: The Naval Academy at Annapolis and other naval officer schools accept African American men for the first time.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The Detroit Race Riot, June 20-21, claims 34 lives including 25 African Americans. Other riots occur in Harlem, Mobile, Alabama, and Beaumont, Texas.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The first black cadets graduate from the Army Flight School at Tuskegee Institute, Alabama.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: By summer, fourteen thousand African American soldiers of the 93rd Infantry Division and the 32nd and 33rd companies of the Womens Army Auxiliary Corps(approximately 300 women) are stationed in the Arizona desert at Fort Huachuca for training. They are the largest concentration of black military personnel in the history of the nation.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Two American Navy Destroyer ships, the USS Mason, and the submarine chaser, PC1264, are staffed entirely by African American crews.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: The black 99th Pursuit Squadron (Tuskegee Airmen) flies its first combat mission in Italy.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On April 3, the U.S. Supreme Court in Smith v. Allwright declares white only political primaries unconstitutional.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Frederick Douglass Patterson establishes the United Negro College Fund on April 25 to help support black colleges and black students. The fund is incorporated in New York.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York, is elected to Congress from Harlem in November.
subject: Black Politics

events: Swedish Nobel Prize winner Gunnar Myrdal publishes An American Dilemma: The Negro Problem and Modern Democracy after being commissioned in 1938 by the Carnegie Corporation to study African American issues.
subject: Segregated America

events: President Franklin Delano Roosevelt dies in Warm Springs, Georgia, on April 12.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: The United Nations is founded in San Francisco on April 25.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: On May 8, Germany surrenders on Victory in Europe (VE) day.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. is named commander of Goodman Field, Kentucky. He is the first African American to command a military base.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Japan surrenders on Victory over Japan (VJ) day ending World War II on September 2. By the end of the war one million African American men and women have served in the U.S. military.
subject: African Americans in World War II

events: Nat King Cole becomes the first African American to have a radio variety show. The show airs on NBC.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Ebony magazine, created by Chicago-based Johnson Publishing Company, published its first issue on November 1.
subject: The Black Press

events: Dr. Charles S. Johnson becomes the first African American president of Fisk University in Nashville.
subject: Black Education

events: The U.S. Supreme Court in Morgan v. Virginia rules that segregation in interstate bus travel is unconstitutional.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: Charles Spurgeon Johnson, President of Fisk University in Nashville, becomes the first African American President of the Southern Sociological Society.
subject: Black Education

events: Channing H. Tobias is the first African American to head the Phelps-Stokes Fund, a philanthropic organization that supports black education.
subject: Black Education

events: On April 10, Jackie Robinson of the Brooklyn Dodgers becomes the first African American to play major league baseball in the 20th Century.
subject: African American Athletes

events: The NAACP petition on racism, An Appeal to the World, is presented to the United Nations.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: John Hope Franklin's From Slavery to Freedom is published. The work will become the most popular textbook on African American history published in the 20th Century.
subject: Black Education

events: On July 26, President Harry Truman issues Executive Order 9981 directing the desegregation of the armed forces.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Alice Coachman becomes the first African American woman to win an Olympic Gold Medal. She wins the high jump competition in the London Olympics.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On October 1, the California Supreme Court voids the law banning interracial marriages in the state.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On May 3, the U.S. Supreme Court rules in Shelley v. Kraemer that state and local governments cannot enforce racially restrictive housing covenants.
subject: housing segregation

events: Timmie Rogers, comedian, dancer, and singer, launches the first all-black variety show, Sugar Hill Times, on CBS Television.
subject: Radio and Television

events: E. Franklin Frazier of Howard University becomes the first African American President of the American Sociological Association.
subject: Black Education

events: In June Wesley Brown becomes the first African American to graduate from the Naval Academy at Annapolis.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Businessman Jesse Blayton, Sr., establishes WERD-AM, the first black owned radio station. It begins broadcasting in Atlanta on October 3.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: William A. Hinton is the first black professor at the Harvard University Medical School.
subject: Black Education

events: U.S. Census, U.S. population: 150,697,361, Black population: 15,044,937 (10 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: On May 1, Gwendolyn Brooks of Chicago becomes the first African American to receive a Pulitzer Prize. She wins the prize in Poetry.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Chuck Cooper, Nathaniel Clifton, and Earl Lloyd become the first African Americans to play professional basketball in the modern National Basketball Association (NBA). Cooper played for the Boston Celtics; Clifton played for the New York Knicks, and Lloyd played for the Washington Capitols.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Juanita Hall became the first African American to win a Tony award. She was honored for her role in the Broadway play, South Pacific.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On May 24, the U.S. Supreme Court rules racial segregation in District of Columbia restaurants is unconstitutional.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On May 24, a mob of 3,500 whites attempt to prevent a black family from moving into a Cicero, Illinois apartment. Illinois Governor Adlai Stevenson calls out the Illinois National Guard to protect the family and restore order.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Harry T. Moore, a Florida NAACP official, is killed by a bomb in Mims, Florida, on December 25.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: Johnson Publishing Company publishes the first issue of Jet, a weekly news magazine for an African American audience.
subject: Black Publications

events: Tuskegee Institute reported no lynchings in the United States for the first time in 71 years of tabulation.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Col. Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. is appointed commander of the 51st Fighter Interceptor Wing in Korea.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Ralph Ellison publishes Invisible Man.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On June 19, Baton Rouge, Louisiana African Americans begin a boycott of their city's segregated municipal bus line.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On December 31, Hulan Jack becomes the first African American borough president of Manhattan. At the time he is the highest ranking black elected official in the nation.
subject: Black Politics

events: James Baldwin publishes his first novel, the semi-autobiographical Go Tell It On The Mountain.
subject: Art and Literature

events: When he joins the Chicago Bears Willie Thrower becomes the first black NFL quarterback in the modern era.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Ralph Bunche becomes the first African American president of the American Political Science Association.
subject: Black Education

events: On May 17, the Supreme Court in Brown v. Board of Education declares segregation in all public schools in the United States unconstitutional, nullifying the earlier judicial doctrine of separate but equal.
subject: Black Education

events: On October 27, Benjamin Oliver Davis, Jr., becomes the first black Air Force general after serving in the Korean War, appointed to brigadier general by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He also is the first African American to command an airbase.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Malcolm X becomes Minister of the Nation of Islam's Harlem Temple 7.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Attorney Frankie Muse Freeman (born Marie Frankie Muse) was the lead attorney for the NAACP in Davis et al. v. the St. Louis Housing Authority which ended racial discrimination in public housing in the city. Freeman was the first black woman to win a major civil rights case.
subject: housing segregation

events: On May 3 in Hernandez v. Texas, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that Mexican Americans and all other racial groups in the U.S. are entitled to equal protection under the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
subject: Civil Rights

events: Fourteen-year-old Chicago resident Emmett Till is lynched while vacationing in Money, Mississippi on August 28.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Chuck Berry, an early breakthrough rock and roll artist, records "Maybellene" with Chicago's Chess Records.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: Rosa Parks refuses to relinquish her bus seat to a white man on December 1, initiating the Montgomery Bus Boycott. Soon afterwards Dr. Martin Luther Kingbecomes the leader of the Boycott.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On January 7 Marian Anderson becomes the first African American to perform with the New York Metropolitan Opera
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On January 15 President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs Executive Order 10590 which creates the President's Committee on Government Policy to enforce the federal government's policy of nondiscrimination in federal employment.
subject: Civil Rights

events: On May 7 Reverend George W. Lee, an NAACP activist, is killed in Belzoni, Mississippi.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On May 31 the U.S. Supreme Court rules in Brown II that public school desegregation must occur with all deliberate speed.
subject: Civil Rights

events: Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the 26 year old pastor of Dexter Avenue Baptist Church, is elected president of the Montgomery Improvement Association which leads the year-long boycott against the city's racially segregated bus line.
subject: Civil Rights Era

events: Autherine Lucy is admitted to the University of Alabama on February 3. She is suspended on February 7 after a riot ensues at the university to protest her presence. Lucy is expelled on February 29.
subject: Black Education

events: On November 11, Nat King Cole becomes the first African American to host a prime time variety show on national television. He appears on NBC.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Harry Belafonte's "Calypso," released by RCA Records, is the first album in history to sell more than one million copies.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: On November 13, the U.S. Supreme Court in Gayle v. Browder bans segregation in intrastate travel, effectively giving a victory to those supporting the Montgomery Bus Boycott.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: On April 10 popular entertainer Nat King Cole is assaulted on stage during a segregated performance at the Municipal Auditorium in Birmingham, Alabama.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The Mississippi Sovereignty Commisison is formed in Jackson, the state captial, to maintain racial segregation in Mississippi.
subject: Segregated America

events: Congress passes the Civil Rights Act of 1957, the first legislation protecting black rights since Reconstruction. The act establishes the Civil Rights section of the Justice Department and empowers federal prosecutors to obtain court injunctions against interference with the right to vote. It also creates the federal Civil Rights Commission with the authority to investigate discriminatory conditions and recommend corrective measures.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: Dorothy Irene Height is appointed president of the National Council of Negro Women, a position she holds for 41 years. She later launches a crusade for justice for black women and works to strengthen the black family.
subject: Black Women

events: In September President Dwight D. Eisenhower sends federal troops to Little Rock, Arkansas to ensure the enforcement of a Federal court order to desegregate Central High School and to protect nine African American students enrolled as part of the order. The troops remain at the high school until the end of the school year.
subject: Black Education

events: The Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights (ACMHR) was founded at a mass meeting in Birmingham, Alabama.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Perry H. Young becomes the first black pilot for a commercial passenger airline (New York Airways).  The following year, 1958, Ruth Carol Taylor becomes the first commercial passenger airline flight attendant (Mohawk Airlines).
subject: Black Transportation

events: On January 12, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) is organized in Atlanta with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. as its first President.
subject: Black Organizations

events: The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater is formed in New York.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Louis E. Lomax becomes the first African American newscaster for a major network station. He is hired by WNTA-TV in New York City.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Althea Gibson becomes the first African American woman to win the U.S. Open tennis championship in Forest Hills.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On January 12, Berry Gordy, Jr., founds Motown Records in Detroit.
subject: Black Business

events: Lorraine Hansberry's "A Raisin in the Sun" opens in New York on March 11 with Sidney Poitier in the starring role. It is the first play by an African American woman to be produced on Broadway.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On April 26, Mack Charles Parker is lynched near Poplarville, Mississippi.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Ella Fitzgerald and William "Count" Basie become the first African American performers to win Grammy awards.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: Census of 1960, U.S. population: 179,323,175, Black population: 18,871,831 (10.6 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: On February 1, 1960, four students from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College in Greensboro begin a sit-in at Woolworth's Drug Store to protest company policy which bans African Americans from sitting at its counters.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On April 15, 150 black and white students gather at Shaw University in Raleigh, North Carolina to form the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC).
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: The Civil Rights Act of 1960 is signed into law by President Dwight D. Eisenhower on May 6. The Act established federal inspection of local voter registration rolls and introduces penalties for anyone who obstructs a citizen's attempt to register to vote or to cast a ballot.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: On Nov. 8, Massachusetts Senator John F. Kennedy defeats Vice President Richard Nixon in one of the closest elections in history. Many observers credit African American voters with Kennedy's narrow margin of victory.
subject: Black Politics

events: On May 4, seven blacks and four whites leave Washington, D.C., for the Deep South on the first Freedom Ride for the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE).
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: Riots on the University of Georgia campus in September fail to prevent the enrollment of the institutions first two African American students, Hamilton Holmes and Charlayne Hunter (Gault).
subject: Black Education

events: Ernie Davis, a running back at Syracuse University, becomes the first African American athlete to receive college football's Heisman Trophy.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On October 1, James Meredith becomes the first black student to enroll at the University of Mississippi. On the day he enters the University, he is escorted by U.S. marshals after federal troops are sent in to suppress rioting and maintain order.
subject: Black Education

events: Martin Luther King, Jr. writes his "Letter from a Birmingham Jail" on April 16.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On May 3, Birmingham police use dogs and fire hoses to attack civil rights demonstrators.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: Despite Governor George Wallace's vow to block the schoolhouse door to prevent their enrollment on June 11, Vivian Malone and James Hood register for classes at the University of Alabama. They are the first African American students to attend the university.
subject: Black Education

events: On June 12, Mississippi NAACP Field Secretary Medgar Evers is assassinated outside his home in Jackson.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: Over 200,000 people gather in Washington, D.C. on August 28 as part of the March on Washington, an unprecedented demonstration demanding civil rights and equal opportunity for African Americans. Dr. Martin Luther King delivers his "I Have a Dream" speech here.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: Former tennis champion Althea Gibson becomes the first African American woman to compete in a Ladies Professional Golf Association (LPGA) tournament in Cincinnati.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On September 15, the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church is bombed in Birmingham, Alabama, killing four girls: Addie Mae Collins, Denise McNair, Carole Robertson and Cynthia Wesley, ages 11-14.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Iota Phi Theta Fraternity is founded on September 19 at Morgan State University in Baltimore.
subject: Black Organizations

events: President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas on November 22.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: Wendell Oliver Scott became the first black driver to win a major NASCAR race, the Grand National (now Winston Cup) race.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Marian Anderson and Ralph Bunche are the first black winners of the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
subject: Humanitarian Awards

events: On January 8, President Lyndon Johnson in his first State of the Union Address declares unconditional war on poverty in America, thus initiating a broad array of government programs designed to assist the poorest citizens of the nation including a disproportionate number of African Americans.
subject: War on Poverty

events: The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) organizes the Mississippi Freedom Summer Project.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On February 25, Cassius Clay (later Muhammad Ali) wins the first of three world heavyweight championships in a bout with Sonny Liston in Miami, Florida.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Sidney Poitier wins the Academy Award for Best Actor for his performance in the film, "Lilies of the Field." He is the first African American male actor to win in that category.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: On March 12, Malcolm X announces his break with the Nation of Islam and his founding of the Muslim Mosque in Harlem. On June 28 he founds the Organization of Afro-American Unity in New York City.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: On June 21 civil rights workers James Chaney, Andrew Goodman and Michael Schwerner are abducted and killed by terrorists in Mississippi.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 is passed by Congress on July 2. The act bans discrimination in all public accommodations and by employers. It also establishes the Equal Opportunity Employment Commission (EEOC) to monitor compliance with the law.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party (MFDP) delegation led by Fannie Lou Hamer is denied seating at the Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City in August.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On August 20, President Lyndon Johnson signs the Economic Opportunity Act, initiating the federally-sponsored War on Poverty. The act includes Head Start, Upward Bound, and Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA).
subject: War on Poverty

events: Malcolm X is assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, New York on February 21.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: On March 7, six hundred Alabama civil rights activists stage a Selma-to-Montgomery protest march to draw attention to the continued denial of black voting rights in the state. The marchers are confronted by Alabama State Troopers whose attack on them at the Edmund Pettus Bridge is carried on national television. On March 21, Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. leads a five-day, 54-mile march retracing the route of the original activists. The 3,300 marchers at the beginning of the trek eventually grow to 25,000 when they reach the Alabama capitol on March 25. After the protest march, President Lyndon Johnson proposes the Voting Rights Act to guarantee black voting throughout the South.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: In March, the White House releases "The Negro Family: The Case for National Action," popularly known as the Moynihan Report.
subject: The Black Family

events: Alex Haley publishes The Autobiography of Malcolm X.
subject: Art and Literature

events: The Voting Rights Act is signed into law on August 6.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: The Watts Uprising (also known as the Watts Rebellion) occurs in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles on August 11-16. Thirty four people are killed and one thousand are injured in the five day confrontation.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Maulana Karenga founds the black nationalist organization US in Los Angeles following the Watts Uprising.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On January 13, Robert Weaver, President Lyndon Baines Johnsons nominee to head the newly created Department of Housing and Urban Development, is confirmed for the post by the U.S. Senate. Weaver becomes the first African American to hold a cabinet post.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: On January 25th Constance Baker Motley is appointed by President Lyndon Baines Johnson to the Federal Bench in New York City. She becomes the first African American woman elevated to a Federal judgeship.
subject: Judicial Appointments

events: In May, Stokely Carmichael becomes chairman of SNCC at its headquarters in Atlanta and publicly embraces the concept of black power.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: On June 5, James Meredith begins a solitary "March Against Fear" for 220 miles from Memphis to Jackson, Mississippi to protest racial discrimination. Soon after crossing into Mississippi Meredith is shot by a sniper. Civil Rights leaders including Martin Luther King (SCLC), Floyd McKissick (CORE) and Stokely Carmichael (SNCC) vow to continue the march which eventually reaches Jackson. While in Greenwood, Carmichael gives his first Black Power speech on June 26.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On October 15, The Black Panther Party is formed in Oakland, California by Bobby Seale and Huey P. Newton.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Andrew F. Brimmer is appointed by President Lyndon Johnson to be the first African American to serve on the Federal Reserve Board.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: James T. Whitehead, Jr., becomes the first African American to pilot a U-2 spy plane.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On November 8, Edward Brooke of Massachusetts becomes the first African American to be popularly elected to the U.S. Senate.
subject: Black Politics

events: On November 8, Julian Bond wins a seat in the Georgia State Senate. However he is denied the seat by the Georgia Legislature because of his opposition to the Vietnam War. Bond is eventually seated after a bitter court battle.
subject: Black Politics

events: Ruby Doris Smith Robinson becomes Executive Director of SNCC.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: On April 4, Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. delivers the speech, "Beyond Vietnam: A Time to Break Silence" at a meeting of Clergy and Laity Concerned at Riverside Church, New York City.  It is his first public criticism of the Vietnam War.
subject: The Civil Rights Movement

events: H. Rap Brown becomes chairman of SNCC on May 12 at its headquarters in Atlanta.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: On June 12, the U.S. Supreme Court in Loving v. Virginia strikes down state interracial marriage bans.
subject: Major Judicial Decisions

events: The six-day Newark Riot begins on July 12 and claims 23 dead, 725 injured and 1,500 arrested.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall takes his seat as the first African American Justice on the United States Supreme Court on July 13.
subject: Judicial Appointments

events: On July 23, the Detroit Race Riot erupts. Between July 23 and July 28, 43 are killed, 1,189 are injured and over 7,000 are arrested.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On November 13, Carl Stokes and Richard G. Hatcher are elected the first black mayors of Cleveland and Gary, Indiana, respectively.
subject: Black Politics

events: Renee Powell becomes the first African American woman to join the Ladies Professional Golf Association (LPGA) Tour.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Albert William Johnson is the first African American awarded a dealership from a major automaker when he opens an Oldsmobile dealership in a predominately black neighborhood in Chicago.
subject: Black Business

events: On February 8, three students at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg are killed by police in what will be known as the Orangeburg Massacre.
subject: Racial Violence

events: The "Report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders," popularly known as the "Kerner Report," is released in March.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee on April 4. In the wake of the assassination 125 cities in 29 states experience uprisings. By April 11, 46 people are killed and 35,000 are injured in these confrontations.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: In April Congress enacts the Civil Rights Act of 1968 which outlaws discrimination in the sale and rental of housing.
subject: Civil Rights Legislation

events: New York Senator and Presidential Candidate Robert F. Kennedy is assassinated on June 5 in Los Angeles.
subject: Political Assassinations

events: On June 19, the Poor Peoples Campaign brings 50,000 demonstrators to Washington, D.C.
subject: War on Poverty

events: Arthur Ashe becomes the first African American to win the Men's Singles competition in the U.S. Open.
subject: African American Athletes

events: San Francisco State University establishes the nations first Black Studies Program in September.
subject: Black Education

events: In November Shirley Chisholm of New York is the first black woman elected to the U.S. Congress.
subject: Black Politics

events: Elizabeth Duncan Koontz becomes the first African American to serve as president of the National Education Association (NEA).
subject: Black Education

events: The Ford Foundation gives one million dollars to Morgan State University, Howard University, and Yale University to help prepare faculty members to teach courses in African American studies.
subject: Black Education

events: On May 5, Moneta Sleet, Jr. of Ebony magazine, becomes the first African American to win a Pulitzer Prize in Photography.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On September 22, the African American Studies Program begins offering courses at Harvard University.
subject: Black Education

events: Robert Chrisman and Nathan Hare publish the first issue of The Black Scholar in November.
subject: Black Education

events: Howard N. Lee becomes the first African American mayor of Chapel Hill, North Carolina. At the time he is the first African American mayor of a predominately white Southern city.
subject: Black Politics

events: On December 4, Chicago police kill Black Panther leaders Fred Hampton and Mark Clarke.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: Jimi Hendrix headlines the Woodstock Musical Festival near Bethel, New York between August 15 and August 18. Over 500,000 people attend what is to that point the largest musical concert in history.
subject: Black Entertainment

events: Census of 1970, U.S. population: 204,765,770, Black population: 22,580,289 (11.1 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: Dr. Clifton Wharton, Jr., is named president of Michigan State University on January 2. He is the first African American to lead a major, predominately white university in the 20th Century.
subject: Black Education

events: On February 18, Bobby Seale and six other six defendants (popularly known as the Chicago Seven) are acquitted of the charge of conspiring to disrupt the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: The first issue of Essence magazine appears in May.
subject: The Black Press

events: On May 15, two students, Philip Lafayette Gibbs and James Earl Green, are killed by police in a confrontation with students at Jackson State University, Jackson, Mississippi.
subject: Racial Violence

events: On July 1, Kenneth Gibson becomes the first black mayor of an eastern city when he assumes the post in Newark, New Jersey.
subject: Black Politics

events: The first issue of Black Enterprise magazine appears in August.
subject: The Black Press

events: The San Rafael, California courthouse shooting on August 7 results in the death of Judge Harold Haley and three others including Jonathan Jackson, the younger brother of imprisoned Black Panther George Jackson. UCLA Philosophy Professor Angela Davis is implicated in the shooting and becomes the subject of a nationwide FBI-led search. Davis is captured and brought to trial. She is acquitted of all charges on June 4, 1972.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: On October 12, Charles Gordone becomes the first African American to win a Pulitzer Prize in Drama for his play, "No Place to Be Somebody."
subject: Art and Literature

events: The Joint Center for Political Studies is established in Washington, D.C.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On January 12th the Congressional Black Caucus is formed in Washington, D.C.
subject: Black Organizastions

events: In July Captain Samuel L. Gravely, Jr. is promoted to Rear Admiral. He becomes the first African American to achieve Flag Rank in the U.S. Navy.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On September 9, nearly 1,200 inmates seize control of half of the New York State Prison at Attica in what will be known as the Attica Prison Riot. Four days later 29 inmates and ten hostages are killed when state troopers and correctional officers suppress the uprising.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: On December 18, Rev. Jesse Jackson founds People United to Save Humanity(PUSH) in Chicago.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Johnson Products, a hair care company, becomes the first black-owned company to be listed on a major U.S. stock exchange (AMEX).
subject: Black Business

events: Leroy Satchel Paige becomes the first former Negro Leagues baseball player inducted int the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, New York.
subject: Black Athletes

events: Beverly Johnson is the first black woman to appear on the cover of a major fashion magazine (Glamour).
subject: Black Entertainment

events: On March 10-12 several thousand African Americans gather in Gary, Indiana, for the first National Black Political Convention.
subject: Black Politics

events: Over the summer New York Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm makes an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination. She is the first African American to campaign for the nomination.
subject: Black Politics

events: In November Barbara Jordan of Houston and Andrew Young of Atlanta become the first black Congressional representatives elected from the U.S. South since 1898.
subject: Black Politics

events: The first Haitian boat people arrive in south Florida.
subject: 20th Century Black Immigrants

events: Wilt Chamberlain of the Los Angeles Lakers becomes the first National Basketball Association player to score over 30,000 points during his career.
subject: Black Athletes

events: On May 29, Thomas Bradley is elected the first black mayor of Los Angeles in the modern era. He is reelected four times and thus holds the mayors office for 20 years.
subject: Black Politics

events: The National Black Feminist Organization is established by Eleanor Holmes Norton.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Marion Wright Edelman creates the Children's Defense Fund.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On October 16, Maynard H. Jackson, Jr. is elected the first black mayor of Atlanta.
subject: Black Politics

events: On Nov. 6, Coleman Young is elected the first black mayor of Detroit.
subject: Black Politics

events: On April 8, Henry (Hank) Aaron of the Atlanta Braves hits his 715th home run surpassing Babe Ruth to become the all-time leader in home runs in major league baseball.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On June 21, U.S. District Judge W. Arthur Garrity issues a court order in Morgan v. Hennigan that initiates a busing program, involving several thousand students.  The order is designed to desegregate the public schools of Boston.
subject: Black Education

events: The largest single gift to date from a black organization is the $132,000 given by the Links, Inc., to the United Negro College Fund on July 1.
subject: Black Organizations

events: On November 5, Mervyn Dymally is elected Lieutenant Governor of California along with George Brown who is elected Lieutenant Governor of Colorado the same day. They are the first African Americans to hold these posts in the 20th century.
subject: Black Politics

events: The Morehouse School of Medicine (Atlanta) becomes the only black medical school established in the United States in the 20th Century. The first dean and president of the Morehouse School of Medicine is Dr. Louis Sullivan who later becomes the U.S. Surgeon General.
subject: Black Education

events: Wallace D. Muhammad assumes control of the Nation of Islam after the death of his father, Elijah Muhammad. He changes the organizations direction and its name to the World Community of al-Islam.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Arthur Ashe becomes the first African American to win the British Men's Singles at Wimbledon.
subject: African American Athletes

events: General Daniel Chappie James of the Air Force becomes the first African American four star general.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On October 12, Frank Robinson becomes the first black Major League Baseball manager when he takes over the Cleveland Indians.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Lee Elder becomes the first African American golfer to compete in the Masters Tournament in Augusta, Georgia.
subject: Black Athletes

events: William Venoid Banks becomes the first African American to own a television station when he launches WGPR-TV in Detroit.
subject: Radio and Television

events: John Hope Franklin is the first African American elected president of the Organization of American Historians (OAH).  Four years later he will be the fiirst African American elected president of the American Historical Association (AHA).
subject: Black Education

events: The United States Naval Academy at Annapolis admits women for the first time in June. Janie L. Mines becomes the first African American women cadet to enter. She graduates in 1980.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: College and university enrollment for African American students rises sharply from 282,000 in 1966 to 1,062,000 in 1976.
subject: Black Education

events: Texas Congresswoman Barbara Jordan becomes the first African American woman to deliver the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention which meets that year in New York City.
subject: Black Politics

events: Clara Stanton Jones of Detroit becomes the first African American elected President of the American Library Association.
subject: Black Education

events: In January, Patricia Harris is appointed by President Jimmy Carter to head Housing and Urban Development. She becomes the first African American woman to hold a cabinet position.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: In January, Congressman Andrew Young is appointed by President Jimmy Carter to be U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. He is the first African American to hold that post.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: The eighth and final night for the miniseries based on Alex Haley's Roots is shown on February 3. This final episode achieves the highest ratings to that point for a single television program.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: On March 8, Henry L. Marsh III became the first African American mayor of Richmond, Virginia
subject: Black Politics

events: In September, Randall Robinson founds TransAfrica (now TransAfrica Forum), a lobbying group for Africa, in Washington, D.C.
subject: Black Organizations

events: Minister Louis Farrakhan breaks with the World Community of al-Islam and becomes the leader of the revived Nation of Islam.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: On June 28, the U.S. Supreme Court in Regents of the University of California Regents v. Bakke narrowly uphold affirmative action as a legal strategy for addressing past discrimination.
subject: Affirmative Action

events: On September 15, Muhammad Ali becomes the first boxer to win the heavyweight championship three times when he defeats Leon Spinks at the Superdome in New Orleans.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Max Robinson becomes the first black network anchor when he begins broadcasting for ABC-TV News from Chicago.
subject: Radio and Television

events: Faye Wattleton becomes the first black woman to head Planned Parenthood.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Jill Brown becomes the first black female pilot for a commercial passenger airline (Texas International Airlines).
subject: Black Transportation

events: The Sugar Hill Gang records "Rappers Delight" in Harlem.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: Franklin Thomas is named president of the Ford Foundation.
subject: Black Education

events: Frank E. Petersen, Jr. becomes the first African American to earn the rank of General in the United States Marines.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: In September Hazel W. Johnson becomes the first African American woman to be promoted to the rank of General in the United States Army.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: Richard Arrington, Jr. is elected the first African American mayor of Birmingham, Alabama.
subject: Black Politics

events: The Nobel Prize in Economics goes to Sir Arthur Lewis of Princeton University. He is the first black person to win the award in a category other than peace.
subject: Black Education

events: Census of 1980, U.S. population: 226,504,825, Black population: 26,482,349 (11.8 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: In January Willie Lewis Brown, Jr. becomes the first African American Speaker in a state legislature when he is selected for the post in the California Assembly. Brown holds the Speakership until 1995 when he is elected Mayor of San Francisco.
subject: Black Politics

events: On May 17-18 rioting breaks out in Liberty City, Florida (near Miami) after police officers are acquitted for killing an unarmed black man. The riot which generates 15 deaths is the worst in the nation since Detroit in 1967.
subject: Racial Violence

events: Toni Cade Bambara's The Salt Eaters wins the American Book Award.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Robert L. Johnson begins operation of Black Entertainment Television (BET) out of Washington, D.C.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: The Mariel boatlift transports 125,000 Cubans to Florida including a large number of Afro-Cubans.
subject: International Refugees

events: The struggle of Rev. Ben Chavis and his followers to block a toxic waste dump in Warren County, North Carolina launches a national campaign against environmental racism.
subject: The Enviroment

events: Bryant Gumbel is named anchor of The Today Show, becoming the first African American to hold the post on a major network.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Michael Jackson's album, Thriller, is released. It will eventually sell 45 million copies worldwide, becoming the best selling album in music history.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: Vanessa Williams becomes the first African American crowned Miss America on September 18 in Atlantic City. In July 1984 she relinquishes her crown to Suzette Charles when nude photos of her appear in Penthouse magazine.
subject: Beauty Pageants

events: On April 12, Harold Washington is elected the first black mayor of Chicago.
subject: Black Politics

events: On August 30, Guion (Guy) S. Bluford, Jr., a crew member on the Challenger,becomes the first African American astronaut to make a space flight.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On November 2, President Ronald Reagan signs a bill establishing January 20 as a federal holiday in honor of Martin Luther King, Jr.
subject: Black Holidays and Celebrations

events: Alice Walker's The Color Purple wins the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Harvey Bernard Gantt becomes the first African American mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina.
subject: Black Politics

events: Robert C. Maynard become the first African American to own the major daily newspaper in a large city when he becomes the majority stockholder of the Oakland Tribune.
subject: Newspapers and Other Print Media

events: On January 2, W. Wilson Goode becomes the first African American mayor of Philadelphia.
subject: Black Politics

events: Rev. Jesse Jackson wins approximately one fourth of the votes cast in the Democratic primaries and caucuses and about one eighth of the convention delegates in a losing bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.
subject: Black Politics

events: In August Carl Lewis wins four Gold Medals at the Olympics in Los Angeles, matching the record set by Jesse Owens in 1936.
subject: African American Athletes

events: In September The Cosby Show starring Bill Cosby makes its television debut. The show runs for eight seasons and will become the most successful series in television history featuring a mostly African American cast.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Russell Simmons forms Def Jam Records in Harlem.
subject: Black Business

events: In May, Philadelphia's African American mayor, Wilson Goode, orders the Philadelphia police to bomb the headquarters of MOVE, a local black nationalist organization. The bombing leaves 11 people dead and 250 homeless.
subject: Black Nationalism and Black Power

events: Gwendolyn Brooks of Chicago is named U.S. Poet-Laureate. She is the first African American to hold that honor.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Grambling State University's football coach Eddie Robinson becomes the coach with the most wins in college football history.
subject: Black Athletes

events: On January 20, the first national Martin Luther King, Jr. holiday is celebrated.
subject: Black Holidays and Celebrations

events: On January 28, Dr. Ronald McNair and six other crew members die when the space shuttle Challenger explodes shortly after launch from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: The Oprah Winfrey Show with Oprah Winfrey as the talk show host, becomes nationally syndicated.
subject: African Americans and the Media

events: Spike Lee releases his first feature film, She's Gotta Have It, initiating a new wave of interest in black films and African American filmmakers.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: On November 22 Mike Tyson defeates Trevor Berbick for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship in a title fight in Las Vegas. At the age of 20, Tyson is the youngest fighter to win the crown.
subject: Black Athletes

events: Rita Dove wins the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On August 6, Reginald Lewis orchestrates the leveraged buyout of Beatrice Foods to become the first African American CEO of a billion dollar corporation.
subject: Black Business

events: Neurosurgeon Dr. Benjamin Carson makes medical history when he leads a seventy-member surgical team at Johns Hopkins Hospital in a 22 hour operation separating Siamese twins (the Binder twins) joined at the cranium.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On October 28, Brigadier General Fred A. Gordon is appointed Commandant of the Cadets at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On December 8, Kurt Lidell Schmoke became the first African American elected mayor of Baltimore by popular vote.
subject: Black Politics

events: August Wilson's play, Fences, wins a Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award.
subject: Art and Literature

events: Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole becomes the first African American woman president of Spelman College in Atlanta, Georgia.
subject: Black Education

events: Aretha Franklin becomes the first woman inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, Ohio.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: In his second try for the Democratic Presidential nomination Jesse L. Jacksonreceives 1,218 delegate votes at the Democratic National Convention on July 20. The number needed for the nomination, which goes to Michael Dukakis, was 2,082.
subject: Black Politics

events: In September, Temple University offers the first Ph.D. in African American Studies.
subject: Black Education

events: On November 4, Comedian Bill Cosby announces his gift of $20 million to Spelman College. This is the largest donation ever made by a black American to a college or university.
subject: Black Education

events: On January 29, Barbara C. Harris is installed as the first woman bishop in the Episcopal (Anglican) Church.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: On February 7, Ronald H. Brown is elected chair of the Democratic National Committee, becoming the first African American to head one of the two major political parties.
subject: Black Politics

events: In March Frederick Drew Gregory becomes the first African American to command a space shuttle when he leads the crew of the Discovery.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On August 10, General Colin L. Powell is named chair of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, the first African American to hold the post.
subject: African Americans and the Military

events: On November 7, L. Douglas Wilder wins the governorship of Virginia, making him the first African American to be popularly elected to that office. On the same day David Dinkins and Norm Rice are the first African Americans elected as mayors of New York and Seattle respectively.
subject: Black Politics

events: Bill White becomes the first African American league president when he is chosen to head Major League Baseball's National League.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Art Shell becomes the first African American head coach in National Football League (NFL) in the post-World War II era when he is hired to lead the Oakland Raiders.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Mahlon Martin becomes the first African American to head the Rockefeller Foundation.
subject: Black Education

events: Census of 1990, U.S. population: 248,709,878, Black population: 29,986,060 (12 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: August Wilson wins a Pulitzer Prize for the play The Piano Lesson.
subject: Art and Literature

events: In November when Sharon Pratt Kelly is elected mayor of Washington, D.C., she becomes the first African American woman to lead a large American city.
subject: Black Politics

events: Marcelite Jordan Harris is the first black woman brigadier general in the U.S. Army and the first woman to command a mostly male battalion.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: Walter E. Massey is the first African American to head the National Science Foundation.
subject: Science and Technology

events: Donna Marie Cheek becomes the first black member of the U.S. Equestrian Team.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Carole Ann-Marie Gist of Detroit, Michigan becomes the first African American to win the Miss USA pageant.
subject: Beauty Pageants

events: On January 15, Roland Burris becomes the first black attorney general of Illinois. From 2009 to 2011 he serves as U.S. Senator from Illionis, completing the unexpired term of Barack Obama who is elected President of the United States.
