subject: Black Politics

events: On March 3, Los Angeles police use force to arrest Rodney King after a San Fernando Valley traffic stop. The beating of King is captured on videotape and broadcast widely prompting, an investigation and subsequent trial of three officers.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: On April 10, Emanuel Cleaver II is sworn in as the first African American mayor of Kansas City, Missouri.
subject: Black Politics

events: On June 18, Wellington Webb becomes the first African American mayor of Denver, Colorado.
subject: Black Politics

events: On October 23, Federal Judge Clarence Thomas, nominated by President George H.W. Bush, is confirmed by the U.S. Senate and takes his seat on the U.S. Supreme Court.
subject: Judicial Appointments

events: Julie Dash releases Daughters of the Dust, the first feature film by an African American woman.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: Physicist Walter Massey becomes the first African American director of the National Science Foundation.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: In March Willie W. Herenton was elected the first African American mayor of Memphis, Tennessee.
subject: Black Politics

events: On April 29, a Simi Valley, California jury acquits the three officers accused of beating Rodney King. The verdict triggers a three day uprising in Los Angeles called the Rodney King Riot that results in over 50 people killed, over 2,000 injured and 8,000 arrested.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: On September 12, Dr. Mae Carol Jemison becomes the first African American woman in space when she travels on board the space shuttle Endeavor.
subject: Exploration and Discovery

events: On November 3, Carol Moseley Braun of Illinois becomes the first African American woman elected to the United States Senate.
subject: Black Politics

events: William "Bill" Pinkney becomes the first African American and only the fourth American to singlehandedly navigate a sailboat around the world.
subject: African American Athletes

events: In April Freeman Robertson Bosley Jr. becomes the first African American mayor of St. Louis, Missouri.
subject: Black Politics

events: Joycelyn M. Elders becomes the first African American and the first woman to be named United States Surgeon General on September 7.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: On October 7, Toni Morrison becomes the first black American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. The work honored is her novel, Beloved.
subject: Art and Literature

events: On June 12, O.J. Simpson's former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman are found stabbed to death. O.J. Simpson emerges as the leading suspect and is subsequently arrested on June 17 after a two hour low speed pursuit of Simpson and his friend Al Cowlings that is seen on television by an estimated 95 million people.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: Corey D. Flourney is elected president of the 400,000 member Future Farmers of America convention in Kansas City, Missouri.
subject: Agricultural Development

events: On May 6, Ron Kirk won the mayoral race in Dallas, becoming the first African American mayor of the city.
subject: Black Politics

events: On October 3, after an eight month televised trial, O.J. Simpson is acquitted of the charges of murder in the deaths of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman.
subject: Crime and Punishment

events: The Million Man March organized by Minister Louis Farrakhan and other political activists is held in Washington, D.C. on October 17.
subject: Black Men

events: Dr. Helene Doris Gayle becomes the first woman and the first African American Director of the National Center for HIV, STD, and TB Prevention for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Lonnie Bristow is the first African American president of the American Medical Association.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Commerce Secretary Ron Brown is killed in a plane crash near Dubrovnik, Croatia on April 3.
subject: Black Politics

events: On April 9, George Walker becomes the first African American to win a Pulitzer Prize for Music. The winning composition, "Lilies for Soprano or Tenor and Orchestra," is based on a poem by Walt Whitman.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: In May, President Bill Clinton signs into law the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act which replaces Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) with state block grants. It also substantially cuts programs designed to help the poor.
subject: The Black Family

events: On November 5, California voters pass Proposition 209 which outlaws affirmative action throughout the state.
subject: Affirmative Action

events: Margaret Dixon is the first African American elected president of the American Association of Retired Persons (AARP).
subject: Health and Medicine

events: On April 13, golfer Tiger Woods wins the Masters Tournament in Augusta, Georgia. At 21 he is the youngest golfer ever to win the title. He is also the first African American to hold the title.
subject: African American Athletes

events: In June, Harvey Johnson, Jr. was sworn in as the first black mayor of Jackson, Mississippi.
subject: Black Politics

events: On October 25 African American women participate in the Million Woman March in Philadelphia, focusing on health care, education, and self-help.
subject: Black Women

events: In December, Lee Patrick Brown becomes Houston's first African American mayor.
subject: Black Politics

events: Wynton Marsalis's "Blood on the Fields" becomes the first jazz composition to win a Pulitzer Prize in Music.
subject: 20th Century Black Music

events: President Bill Clinton makes a formal apology to black men exploited in the U.S. Public Health Service Tuskegee Syphilis Study.
subject: Health and Medicine

events: Lois Jean White is the first African American to be elected president of the National Parent Teacher Association (PTA).
subject: Black Education

events: On June 7, churchgoers discover the dismembered body of James Byrd, Jr., in Jasper, Texas. It is later determined that three white supremacists chained Byrd, who is black, to the back of a pick-up truck and dragged him to his death.
subject: Racial Violence

events: President Bill Clinton appoints prominent historian John Hope Franklin to lead the President's Commission on Race to promote a national dialogue on issues affecting African Americans in the United States, and to ease racial tensions.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: Carolyn Jefferson-Jenkins becomes the first African American president of the National League of Women Voters.
subject: Black Politics

events: On January 13, after thirteen seasons and six NBA championships, professional basketball star Michael Jordan retires from the game as a player.
subject: African American Athletes

events: On September 10, Serena Williams wins the U.S. Open Womens Singles Tennis Championship in Flushing Meadows, the first African American woman to do so since Althea Gibson's win in 1958.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Maurice Ashley becomes the world's first black chess grandmasters, the game's highest rank.
subject: African American Athletes

events: Census of 2000, U.S. population: 281,421,906, Black population: 34,658,190 (12.3 percent)
subject: Black Population

events: Rev. Vashti M. McKenzie becomes the first woman bishop of the African Methodist Zion Church.
subject: 20th Century Black Religion

events: Lillian Elaine Fishbourne is the first black woman admiral in the U.S. Navy.
subject: African Americans in the Military

events: In January President-elect George W. Bush nominates Colin Powell to be Secretary of State.  Condoleezza Rice is also appointed to the positon of National Security Advisor for the Bush Administration.  This is the first time either post has been held by African Americans.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: In November Shirley Clarke Franklin becomes the first African American woman to head the government of a major Southern city whe she is elected mayor of Atlanta.
subject: Black Politics

events: In March, Halle Berry and Denzel Washington win Oscars for best actress and best actor for their portrayals in Monster’s Ball and Training Day respectively.
subject: Black Hollywood

events: Dennis Archer, former Mayor of Detroit, becomes the first African American to be elected President of the American Bar Association.
subject: The Legal System

events: Significant population shifts and reduced resistance to residential integration result in more African Americans living in the suburbs of Los Angeles and Seattle than in their city limits.
subject: Black Population

events: On June 23 the U.S. Supreme Court in Grutter v. Bollinger upholds the University of Michigan Law School's admission policy which supports affirmative action. In the simultaneously heard Gratz v. Bollinger case, the Supreme Court requires the University of Michigan to dismantle its affirmative action policy for undergraduate admissions.
subject: Affirmative Action

events: On November 2, State Senator Barack Obama is elected to the U.S. Senate from Illinois.  He becomes the second African American elected to the Senate from that state and only the fifth black senator in U.S. history.
subject: Black Politics

events: In January Condoleezza Rice becomes Secretary of State.  She is the second woman and the first African American woman to hold the post.
subject: Presidential Appointments

events: On August 30, Hurricane Katrina hits the Gulf Coast, taking an estimated 1,700 lives.  The vast majority of the deaths are in Louisiana including heavily African American New Orleans.
subject: The Environment

events: With the Democratic takeover of both the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate in the November mid-term elections, for the first time in U.S. history four African American members of Congress chair full committees in the House: Rep. John Conyers(Mi.), Judiciary, Rep. Juanita Millender McDonald (Ca.), House Administration Committee, Rep. Charles Rangel (N.Y.), House Ways and Means, and Rep. Bennie G. Thompson (Ms.), Homeland Security.
subject: Black Politics

events: On November 7 Deval Patrick is elected Governor of Massachusetts.  He becomes the second African American in the nation, after L. Douglas Wilder in Virginia in 1989, to be popularly elected to this position.
subject: Black Politics

events: The U.S. Supreme Court in Parents Involved in Community Schools v. Seattle School District No. 1, and Meredith v. Jefferson County (Kentucky) Board of Education, rules that race cannot be a factor in the determination of school assignments.
subject: Affirmative Action

events: On March 17, David A. Paterson, is sworn in as Governor of New York upon the resignation of the prior governor, Elliott Spitzer.  Paterson is the first legally blind American Governor, the first black Governor of New York State, and only the fourth black Governor of any state.
subject: Black Politics

events: On November 4, Barack Obama of Illinois, the only sitting African American U.S. Senator, is elected President of the United States.  Obama wins the election decisively and becomes the first African American elected to this office.
subject: Black Politics

events: Barack Obama is sworn in as the 44th President of the United States on January 20.
subject: Post-1970 Politics

events: Former Maryland Lt. Governor Michael S. Steele becomes Chairman of National Republican Committee and thus effectively heads the Republican Party.
subject: Post-1970 Politics
